column2: '16Oct'
column3: 1)	" Thank you
column4: Jeremy. I appreciate your -- your question
column5: and thank you for being here this evening and to all of those from Nassau County that have come
column6: thank you for your time. Thank you to Hofstra University and to Candy Crowley for organizing and leading this -- this event. Thank you
column7: Mr. President
column8: also for being part of this -- this debate.  Your question -- your question is one that's being asked by college kids all over this country. I was in Pennsylvania with someone who had just graduated -- this was in Philadelphia -- and she said
column9: ""I've got my degree. I can't find a job. I've got three part- time jobs. They're just barely enough to pay for my food and pay for an apartment. I can't begin to pay back my student loans.""  So what we have to do is two things. We have to make sure that we make it easier for kids to afford college.

column1: And also make sure that when they get out of college
column2: there's a job. When I was governor of Massachusetts
column3: to get a high school degree
column4: you had to pass an exam. If you graduated in the top quarter of your airlines
column5: we gave you a John and Abigail Adams scholarship
column6: four years tuition free in the college of your choice in Massachusetts
column7: it's a public institution. I want to make sure we keep our Pell grant program growing. We're also going to have our loan program
column8: so that people are able to afford school. But the key thing is to make sure you can get a job when you get out of school. And what's happened over the last four years has been very
column9: very hard for America's young people. I want you to be able to get a job.  I know what it takes to get this economy going. With half of college kids graduating this year without a college -- excuse me
column10: without a job. And without a college level job
column11: that's just unacceptable.  And likewise you've got more and more debt on your back. So more debt and less jobs. I'm going to change that. I know what it takes to create good jobs again. I know what it takes to make sure that you have the kind of opportunity you deserve. And kids across this country are going to recognize
column12: we're bringing back an economy.  It's not going to be like the last four years. The middle-class has been crushed over the last four years
column13: and jobs have been too scarce. I know what it takes to bring them back
column14: and I'm going to do that
column15: and make sure that when you graduate -- when do you graduate?

column1: 2014. When you come out in 2014
column2: I presume I'm going to be president. I'm going to make sure you get a job. Thanks Jeremy. Yeah
column3: you bet.

column1: Jeremy
column2: first of all
column3: your future is bright. And the fact that you're making an investment in higher education is critical. Not just to you
column4: but to the entire nation. Now
column5: the most important thing we can do is to make sure that we are creating jobs in this country. But not just jobs
column6: good paying jobs. Ones that can support a family.

column1: And what I want to do
column2: is build on the five million jobs that we've created over the last 30 months in the private sector alone. And there are a bunch of things we can do to make sure your future is bright. Number one
column3: I want to build manufacturing jobs in this country again. Now when Governor Romney said we should let Detroit go bankrupt. I said we're going to bet on American workers and the American auto industry and it's come surging back.  I want to do that in industries
column4: not just in Detroit
column5: but all across the country and that means we change our tax code so we're giving incentives to companies that are investing here in the United States and creating jobs here.  It also means we're helping them and small businesses to export all around the world to new markets.  Number two
column6: we've got to make sure that we have the best education system in the world. And the fact that you're going to college is great
column7: but I want everybody to get a great education and we've worked hard to make sure that student loans are available for folks like you
column8: but I also want to make sure that community colleges are offering slots for workers to get retrained for the jobs that are out there right now and the jobs of the future.  Number three
column9: we've got to control our own energy. Now
column10: not only oil and natural gas
column11: which we've been investing in; but also
column12: we've got to make sure we're building the energy source of the future
column13: not just thinking about next year
column14: but ten years from now
column15: 20 years from now. That's why we've invested in solar and wind and biofuels
column16: energy efficient cars.  We've got to reduce our deficit
column17: but we've got to do it in a balanced way. Asking the wealthy to pay a little bit more along with cuts so that we can invest in education like yours.  And let's take the money that we've been spending on war over the last decade to rebuild America
column18: roads
column19: bridges schools. We do those things
column20: not only is your future going to be bright but America's future is going to bright as well.

column1: Well what you're seeing in this country is 23 million people struggling to find a job. And a lot of them
column2: as you say
column3: Candy
column4: have been out of work for a long
column5: long
column6: long time. The president's policies have been exercised over the last four years and they haven't put Americans back to work. We have fewer people working today than we had when the president took office. If the -- the unemployment rate was 7.8 percent when he took office
column7: it's 7.8 percent now. But if you calculated that unemployment rate
column8: taking back the people who dropped out of the workforce
column9: it would be 10.7 percent.  We have not made the progress we need to make to put people back to work. That's why I put out a five-point plan that gets America 12 million new jobs in four years and rising take-home pay. It's going to help Jeremy get a job when he comes out of school. It's going to help people across the country that are unemployed right now.  And one thing that the president said
column10: which I want to make sure that we understand
column11: he said that I said we should take Detroit bankrupt. And that's right. My plan was to have the company go through bankruptcy like 7-Eleven did and Macy's and Condell (ph) Airlines and come out stronger.  And I know he keeps saying
column12: you want to take Detroit bankrupt. Well
column13: the president took Detroit bankrupt. You took General Motors bankrupt. You took Chrysler bankrupt. So when you say that I wanted to take the auto industry bankrupt
column14: you actually did.  And I think it's important to know that that was a process that was necessary to get those companies back on their feet
column15: so they could start hiring more people. That was precisely what I recommended and ultimately what happened.

column1: Candy
column2: what Governor Romney said just isn't true. He wanted to take them into bankruptcy without providing them any way to stay open. And we would have lost a million jobs. And that -- don't take my word for it
column3: take the executives at GM and Chrysler
column4: some of whom are Republicans
column5: may even support Governor Romney. But they'll tell you his prescription wasn't going to work. And Governor Romney's says he's got a five-point plan? Governor Romney doesn't have a five-point plan. He has a one-point plan. And that plan is to make sure that folks at the top play by a different set of rules. That's been his philosophy in the private sector
column6: that's been his philosophy as governor
column7: that's been his philosophy as a presidential candidate.  You can make a lot of money and pay lower tax rates than somebody who makes a lot less. You can ship jobs overseas and get tax breaks for it. You can invest in a company
column8: bankrupt it
column9: lay off the workers
column10: strip away their pensions
column11: and you still make money.  That's exactly the philosophy that we've seen in place for the last decade. That's what's been squeezing middle class families.  And we have fought back for four years to get out of that mess. The last thing we need to do is to go back to the very same policies that got us there.

column1: That -- that Detroit -- that Detroit answer...
... that Detroit answer...
... and the rest of the answer
column2: way off the mark.

column1: And let's take the money that we've been spending on war over the last decade to rebuild America, roads, bridges schools. We do those things, not only is your future going to be bright but America's future is going to bright as well. column2: '16Oct'
column3: 1)	" Thank you
column4: Jeremy. I appreciate your -- your question
column5: and thank you for being here this evening and to all of those from Nassau County that have come
column6: thank you for your time. Thank you to Hofstra University and to Candy Crowley for organizing and leading this -- this event. Thank you
column7: Mr. President
column8: also for being part of this -- this debate.  Your question -- your question is one that's being asked by college kids all over this country. I was in Pennsylvania with someone who had just graduated -- this was in Philadelphia -- and she said
column9: ""I've got my degree. I can't find a job. I've got three part- time jobs. They're just barely enough to pay for my food and pay for an apartment. I can't begin to pay back my student loans.""  So what we have to do is two things. We have to make sure that we make it easier for kids to afford college.

column1: And also make sure that when they get out of college
column2: there's a job. When I was governor of Massachusetts
column3: to get a high school degree
column4: you had to pass an exam. If you graduated in the top quarter of your airlines
column5: we gave you a John and Abigail Adams scholarship
column6: four years tuition free in the college of your choice in Massachusetts
column7: it's a public institution. I want to make sure we keep our Pell grant program growing. We're also going to have our loan program
column8: so that people are able to afford school. But the key thing is to make sure you can get a job when you get out of school. And what's happened over the last four years has been very
column9: very hard for America's young people. I want you to be able to get a job.  I know what it takes to get this economy going. With half of college kids graduating this year without a college -- excuse me
column10: without a job. And without a college level job
column11: that's just unacceptable.  And likewise you've got more and more debt on your back. So more debt and less jobs. I'm going to change that. I know what it takes to create good jobs again. I know what it takes to make sure that you have the kind of opportunity you deserve. And kids across this country are going to recognize
column12: we're bringing back an economy.  It's not going to be like the last four years. The middle-class has been crushed over the last four years
column13: and jobs have been too scarce. I know what it takes to bring them back
column14: and I'm going to do that
column15: and make sure that when you graduate -- when do you graduate?

column1: 2014. When you come out in 2014
column2: I presume I'm going to be president. I'm going to make sure you get a job. Thanks Jeremy. Yeah
column3: you bet.

column1: Jeremy
column2: first of all
column3: your future is bright. And the fact that you're making an investment in higher education is critical. Not just to you
column4: but to the entire nation. Now
column5: the most important thing we can do is to make sure that we are creating jobs in this country. But not just jobs
column6: good paying jobs. Ones that can support a family.

column1: And what I want to do
column2: is build on the five million jobs that we've created over the last 30 months in the private sector alone. And there are a bunch of things we can do to make sure your future is bright. Number one
column3: I want to build manufacturing jobs in this country again. Now when Governor Romney said we should let Detroit go bankrupt. I said we're going to bet on American workers and the American auto industry and it's come surging back.  I want to do that in industries
column4: not just in Detroit
column5: but all across the country and that means we change our tax code so we're giving incentives to companies that are investing here in the United States and creating jobs here.  It also means we're helping them and small businesses to export all around the world to new markets.  Number two
column6: we've got to make sure that we have the best education system in the world. And the fact that you're going to college is great
column7: but I want everybody to get a great education and we've worked hard to make sure that student loans are available for folks like you
column8: but I also want to make sure that community colleges are offering slots for workers to get retrained for the jobs that are out there right now and the jobs of the future.  Number three
column9: we've got to control our own energy. Now
column10: not only oil and natural gas
column11: which we've been investing in; but also
column12: we've got to make sure we're building the energy source of the future
column13: not just thinking about next year
column14: but ten years from now
column15: 20 years from now. That's why we've invested in solar and wind and biofuels
column16: energy efficient cars.  We've got to reduce our deficit
column17: but we've got to do it in a balanced way. Asking the wealthy to pay a little bit more along with cuts so that we can invest in education like yours.  And let's take the money that we've been spending on war over the last decade to rebuild America
column18: roads
column19: bridges schools. We do those things
column20: not only is your future going to be bright but America's future is going to bright as well.

column1: Well what you're seeing in this country is 23 million people struggling to find a job. And a lot of them
column2: as you say
column3: Candy
column4: have been out of work for a long
column5: long
column6: long time. The president's policies have been exercised over the last four years and they haven't put Americans back to work. We have fewer people working today than we had when the president took office. If the -- the unemployment rate was 7.8 percent when he took office
column7: it's 7.8 percent now. But if you calculated that unemployment rate
column8: taking back the people who dropped out of the workforce
column9: it would be 10.7 percent.  We have not made the progress we need to make to put people back to work. That's why I put out a five-point plan that gets America 12 million new jobs in four years and rising take-home pay. It's going to help Jeremy get a job when he comes out of school. It's going to help people across the country that are unemployed right now.  And one thing that the president said
column10: which I want to make sure that we understand
column11: he said that I said we should take Detroit bankrupt. And that's right. My plan was to have the company go through bankruptcy like 7-Eleven did and Macy's and Condell (ph) Airlines and come out stronger.  And I know he keeps saying
column12: you want to take Detroit bankrupt. Well
column13: the president took Detroit bankrupt. You took General Motors bankrupt. You took Chrysler bankrupt. So when you say that I wanted to take the auto industry bankrupt
column14: you actually did.  And I think it's important to know that that was a process that was necessary to get those companies back on their feet
column15: so they could start hiring more people. That was precisely what I recommended and ultimately what happened.

column1: Candy
column2: what Governor Romney said just isn't true. He wanted to take them into bankruptcy without providing them any way to stay open. And we would have lost a million jobs. And that -- don't take my word for it
column3: take the executives at GM and Chrysler
column4: some of whom are Republicans
column5: may even support Governor Romney. But they'll tell you his prescription wasn't going to work. And Governor Romney's says he's got a five-point plan? Governor Romney doesn't have a five-point plan. He has a one-point plan. And that plan is to make sure that folks at the top play by a different set of rules. That's been his philosophy in the private sector
column6: that's been his philosophy as governor
column7: that's been his philosophy as a presidential candidate.  You can make a lot of money and pay lower tax rates than somebody who makes a lot less. You can ship jobs overseas and get tax breaks for it. You can invest in a company
column8: bankrupt it
column9: lay off the workers
column10: strip away their pensions
column11: and you still make money.  That's exactly the philosophy that we've seen in place for the last decade. That's what's been squeezing middle class families.  And we have fought back for four years to get out of that mess. The last thing we need to do is to go back to the very same policies that got us there.

column1: That -- that Detroit -- that Detroit answer...
... that Detroit answer...
... and the rest of the answer
column2: way off the mark.

column1: And let's take the money that we've been spending on war over the last decade to rebuild America, roads, bridges schools. We do those things, not only is your future going to be bright but America's future is going to bright as well. column148: ""But they'll tell you his prescription wasn't going to work.""

column2: '16Oct'
column3: 10)	" Boy
column4: great question and important question
column5: because you're absolutely right. The place where we've seen manufacturing go has been China. China is now the largest manufacturer in the world. It used to be the United States of America. A lot of good people have lost jobs. A half a million manufacturing jobs have been lost in the last four years. That's total over the last four years. One of the reasons for that is that people think it's more attractive in some cases to go offshore than to stay here. We have made it less attractive for enterprises to stay here than to go offshore from time to time. What I will do as president is make sure it's more attractive to come to America again.  This is the way we're going to create jobs in this country. It's not by trickle-down government
column6: saying we're going to take more money from people and hire more government workers
column7: raise more taxes
column8: put in place more regulations. Trickle-down government has never worked here
column9: has never worked anywhere.  I want to make America the most attractive place in the world for entrepreneurs
column10: for small business
column11: for big business
column12: to invest and grow in America.  Now
column13: we're going to have to make sure that as we trade with other nations that they play by the rules. And China hasn't. One of the reasons -- or one of the ways they don't play by the rules is artificially holding down the value of their currency. Because if they put their currency down low
column14: that means their prices on their goods are low. And that makes them advantageous in the marketplace.  We lose sales. And manufacturers here in the U.S. making the same products can't compete. China has been a currency manipulator for years and years and years. And the president has a regular opportunity to label them as a currency manipulator
column15: but refuses to do so.  On day one
column16: I will label China a currency manipulator
column17: which will allow me as president to be able to put in place
column18: if necessary
column19: tariffs where I believe that they are taking unfair advantage of our manufacturers.  So we're going to make sure that people we trade with around the world play by the rules. But let me -- let me not just stop there. Don't forget
column20: what's key to bringing back jobs here is not just finding someone else to punish
column21: and I'm going to be strict with people who we trade with to make sure they -- they follow the law and play by the rules
column22: but it's also to make America the most attractive place in the world for businesses of all kinds. That's why I want to down the tax rates on small employers
column23: big employers
column24: so they want to be here. Canada's tax rate on companies is now 15 percent. Ours is 35 percent. So if you're starting a business
column25: where would you rather start it? We have to be competitive if we're going to create more jobs here.  Regulations have quadrupled. The rate of regulations quadrupled under this president. I talk to small businesses across the country. They say
column26: ""We feel like we're under attack from our own government."" I want to make sure that regulators see their job as encouraging small business
column27: not crushing it. And there's no question but that Obamacare has been an extraordinary deterrent to enterprises of all kinds hiring people.  My priority is making sure that we get more people hired. If we have more people hired
column28: if we get back manufacturing jobs
column29: if we get back all kinds of jobs into this country
column30: then you're going to see rising incomes again. The reason incomes are down is because unemployment is so high. I know what it takes to get this to happen
column31: and my plan will do that
column32: and one part of it is to make sure that we keep China playing by the rules.

column1: OK. We need to create jobs here. And both Governor Romney and I agree actually that we should lower our corporate tax rate. It's too high. But there's a difference in terms of how we would do it. I want to close loopholes that allow companies to deduct expenses when they move to China; that allow them to profit offshore and not have to get taxed
column2: so they have tax advantages offshore. All those changes in our tax code would make a difference.  Now
column3: Governor Romney actually wants to expand those tax breaks. One of his big ideas when it comes to corporate tax reform would be to say
column4: if you invest overseas
column5: you make profits overseas
column6: you don't have to pay U.S. taxes.  But
column7: of course
column8: if you're a small business or a mom-and-pop business or a big business starting up here
column9: you've got to pay even the reduced rate that Governor Romney's talking about.  And it's estimated that that will create 800
column10: 000 new jobs. The problem is they'll be in china. Or India. Or Germany.  That's not the way we're going to create jobs here. The way we're going to create jobs here is not just to change our tax code
column11: but also to double our exports. And we are on pace to double our exports
column12: one of the commitments I made when I was president. That's creating tens of thousands of jobs all across the country. That's why we've kept on pushing trade deals
column13: but trade deals that make sure that American workers and American businesses are getting a good deal.  Now
column14: Governor Romney talked about China
column15: as I already indicated. In the private sector
column16: Governor Romney's company invested in what were called pioneers of outsourcing. That's not my phrase. That's what reporters called it.  And as far as currency manipulation
column17: the currency has actually gone up 11 percent since I've been president because we have pushed them hard. And we've put unprecedented trade pressure on China. That's why exports have significantly increased under my presidency. That's going to help to create jobs here.

column1: The answer is very straightforward. We can compete with anyone in the world as long as the playing field is level. China's been cheating over the years. One by holding down the value of their currency. Number two
column2: by stealing our intellectual property; our designs
column3: our patents
column4: our technology. There's even an Apple store in China that's a counterfeit Apple store
column5: selling counterfeit goods. They hack into our computers. We will have to have people play on a fair basis
column6: that's number one. Number two
column7: we have to make America the most attractive place for entrepreneurs
column8: for people who want to expand their business. That's what brings jobs in. The president's characterization of my tax plan...  (CROSSTALK)

column1: ...is completely...is completely... (CROSSTALK)
...is completely false. Let me tell you...
Candy
column2: there are some jobs that are not going to come back. Because they are low wage
column3: low skill jobs. I want high wage
column4: high skill jobs. That's why we have to emphasize manufacturing. That's why we have to invest in advanced manufacturing. That's why we've got to make sure that we've got the best science and research in the world. And when we talk about deficits
column5: if we're adding to our deficit for tax cuts for folks who don't need them
column6: and we're cutting investments in research and science that will create the next Apple
column7: create the next new innovation that will sell products around the world
column8: we will lose that race. If we're not training engineers to make sure that they are equipped here in this country. Then companies won't come here. Those investments are what's going to help to make sure that we continue to lead this world economy
column9: not just next year
column10: but 10 years from now
column11: 50 years from now
column12: 100 years from now.

column1: Government does not create jobs. Government does not create jobs.

column25: where would you rather start it? We have to be competitive if we're going to create more jobs here.  Regulations have quadrupled. The rate of regulations quadrupled under this president. I talk to small businesses across the country. They say
column26: ""We feel like we're under attack from our own government."" I want to make sure that regulators see their job as encouraging small business
column27: not crushing it. And there's no question but that Obamacare has been an extraordinary deterrent to enterprises of all kinds hiring people.  My priority is making sure that we get more people hired. If we have more people hired
column28: if we get back manufacturing jobs
column29: if we get back all kinds of jobs into this country
column30: then you're going to see rising incomes again. The reason incomes are down is because unemployment is so high. I know what it takes to get this to happen
column31: and my plan will do that
column32: and one part of it is to make sure that we keep China playing by the rules.

column1: OK. We need to create jobs here. And both Governor Romney and I agree actually that we should lower our corporate tax rate. It's too high. But there's a difference in terms of how we would do it. I want to close loopholes that allow companies to deduct expenses when they move to China; that allow them to profit offshore and not have to get taxed
column2: so they have tax advantages offshore. All those changes in our tax code would make a difference.  Now
column3: Governor Romney actually wants to expand those tax breaks. One of his big ideas when it comes to corporate tax reform would be to say
column4: if you invest overseas
column5: you make profits overseas
column6: you don't have to pay U.S. taxes.  But
column7: of course
column8: if you're a small business or a mom-and-pop business or a big business starting up here
column9: you've got to pay even the reduced rate that Governor Romney's talking about.  And it's estimated that that will create 800
column10: 000 new jobs. The problem is they'll be in china. Or India. Or Germany.  That's not the way we're going to create jobs here. The way we're going to create jobs here is not just to change our tax code
column11: but also to double our exports. And we are on pace to double our exports
column12: one of the commitments I made when I was president. That's creating tens of thousands of jobs all across the country. That's why we've kept on pushing trade deals
column13: but trade deals that make sure that American workers and American businesses are getting a good deal.  Now
column14: Governor Romney talked about China
column15: as I already indicated. In the private sector
column16: Governor Romney's company invested in what were called pioneers of outsourcing. That's not my phrase. That's what reporters called it.  And as far as currency manipulation
column17: the currency has actually gone up 11 percent since I've been president because we have pushed them hard. And we've put unprecedented trade pressure on China. That's why exports have significantly increased under my presidency. That's going to help to create jobs here.

column1: The answer is very straightforward. We can compete with anyone in the world as long as the playing field is level. China's been cheating over the years. One by holding down the value of their currency. Number two
column2: by stealing our intellectual property; our designs
column3: our patents
column4: our technology. There's even an Apple store in China that's a counterfeit Apple store
column5: selling counterfeit goods. They hack into our computers. We will have to have people play on a fair basis
column6: that's number one. Number two
column7: we have to make America the most attractive place for entrepreneurs
column8: for people who want to expand their business. That's what brings jobs in. The president's characterization of my tax plan...  (CROSSTALK)

column1: ...is completely...is completely... (CROSSTALK)
...is completely false. Let me tell you...
Candy
column2: there are some jobs that are not going to come back. Because they are low wage
column3: low skill jobs. I want high wage
column4: high skill jobs. That's why we have to emphasize manufacturing. That's why we have to invest in advanced manufacturing. That's why we've got to make sure that we've got the best science and research in the world. And when we talk about deficits
column5: if we're adding to our deficit for tax cuts for folks who don't need them
column6: and we're cutting investments in research and science that will create the next Apple
column7: create the next new innovation that will sell products around the world
column8: we will lose that race. If we're not training engineers to make sure that they are equipped here in this country. Then companies won't come here. Those investments are what's going to help to make sure that we continue to lead this world economy
column9: not just next year
column10: but 10 years from now
column11: 50 years from now
column12: 100 years from now.

column1: Government does not create jobs. Government does not create jobs.

column2: '16Oct'
column3: 11)	" Barry? Where is Barry?

column1: Thank you
column2: and that's an opportunity for me
column3: and I appreciate it. In the nature of a campaign
column4: it seems that some campaigns are focused on attacking a person rather than prescribing their own future and the things they'd like to do. In the course of that
column5: I think the president's campaign has tried to characterize me as -- as someone who's very different than who I am.  I care about 100 percent of the American people. I want 100 percent of the American people to have a bright and prosperous future. I care about our kids. I understand what it takes to make a bright and prosperous future for America again. I spent my life in the private sector
column6: not in government. I'm a guy who wants to help with the experience I have
column7: the American people.  My -- my passion probably flows from the fact that I believe in God. And I believe we're all children of the same God. I believe we have a responsibility to care for one another. I -- I served as a missionary for my church. I served as a pastor in my congregation for about 10 years. I've sat across the table from people who were out of work and worked with them to try and find new work or to help them through tough times.  I went to the Olympics when they were in trouble to try and get them on track. And as governor of my state
column8: I was able to get 100 percent of my people insured
column9: all my kids
column10: about 98 percent of the adults. I was able also to get our schools ranked number one in the nation
column11: so 100 percent of our kids would have a bright opportunity for a future.

column1: I understand that I can get this country on track again. We don't have to settle for what we're going through. We don't have to settle for gasoline at four bucks. We don't have to settle for unemployment at a chronically high level. We don't have to settle for 47 million people on food stamps. We don't have to settle for 50 percent of kids coming out of college not able to get work. We don't have to settle for 23 million people struggling to find a good job. If I become president
column2: I'll get America working again. I will get us on track to a balanced budget. The president hasn't. I will. I'll make sure we can reform Medicare and Social Security to preserve them for coming -- coming generations. The president said he would. He didn't.

column1: I'll get our incomes up. And by the way
column2: I've done these things. I served as governor and showed I could get them done.

column1: Barry
column2: I think a lot of this campaign
column3: maybe over the last four years
column4: has been devoted to this nation that I think government creates jobs
column5: that that somehow is the answer. That's not what I believe. I believe that the free enterprise system is the greatest engine of prosperity the world's ever known.  I believe in self-reliance and individual initiative and risk takers being rewarded. But I also believe that everybody should have a fair shot and everybody should do their fair share and everybody should play by the same rules
column6: because that's how our economy's grown. That's how we built the world's greatest middle class.  And -- and that is part of what's at stake in this election. There's a fundamentally different vision about how we move our country forward.  I believe Governor Romney is a good man. Loves his family
column7: cares about his faith. But I also believe that when he said behind closed doors that 47 percent of the country considered themselves victims who refuse personal responsibility
column8: think about who he was talking about.  Folks on Social Security who've worked all their lives. Veterans who've sacrificed for this country. Students who are out there trying to hopefully advance their own dreams
column9: but also this country's dreams. Soldiers who are overseas fighting for us right now. People who are working hard every day
column10: paying payroll tax
column11: gas taxes
column12: but don't make enough income.  And I want to fight for them. That's what I've been doing for the last four years. Because if they succeed
column13: I believe the country succeeds.  When my grandfather fought in World War II and he came back and he got a G.I. Bill and that allowed him to go to college
column14: that wasn't a handout. That was something that advanced the entire country. And I want to make sure that the next generation has those same opportunities. That's why I'm asking for your vote and that's why I'm asking for another four years.

column1: I care about 100 percent of the American people. I want 100 percent of the American people to have a bright and prosperous future. column2: '16Oct'
column3: 11)	" Barry? Where is Barry?

column1: Thank you
column2: and that's an opportunity for me
column3: and I appreciate it. In the nature of a campaign
column4: it seems that some campaigns are focused on attacking a person rather than prescribing their own future and the things they'd like to do. In the course of that
column5: I think the president's campaign has tried to characterize me as -- as someone who's very different than who I am.  I care about 100 percent of the American people. I want 100 percent of the American people to have a bright and prosperous future. I care about our kids. I understand what it takes to make a bright and prosperous future for America again. I spent my life in the private sector
column6: not in government. I'm a guy who wants to help with the experience I have
column7: the American people.  My -- my passion probably flows from the fact that I believe in God. And I believe we're all children of the same God. I believe we have a responsibility to care for one another. I -- I served as a missionary for my church. I served as a pastor in my congregation for about 10 years. I've sat across the table from people who were out of work and worked with them to try and find new work or to help them through tough times.  I went to the Olympics when they were in trouble to try and get them on track. And as governor of my state
column8: I was able to get 100 percent of my people insured
column9: all my kids
column10: about 98 percent of the adults. I was able also to get our schools ranked number one in the nation
column11: so 100 percent of our kids would have a bright opportunity for a future.

column1: I understand that I can get this country on track again. We don't have to settle for what we're going through. We don't have to settle for gasoline at four bucks. We don't have to settle for unemployment at a chronically high level. We don't have to settle for 47 million people on food stamps. We don't have to settle for 50 percent of kids coming out of college not able to get work. We don't have to settle for 23 million people struggling to find a good job. If I become president
column2: I'll get America working again. I will get us on track to a balanced budget. The president hasn't. I will. I'll make sure we can reform Medicare and Social Security to preserve them for coming -- coming generations. The president said he would. He didn't.

column1: I'll get our incomes up. And by the way
column2: I've done these things. I served as governor and showed I could get them done.

column1: Barry
column2: I think a lot of this campaign
column3: maybe over the last four years
column4: has been devoted to this nation that I think government creates jobs
column5: that that somehow is the answer. That's not what I believe. I believe that the free enterprise system is the greatest engine of prosperity the world's ever known.  I believe in self-reliance and individual initiative and risk takers being rewarded. But I also believe that everybody should have a fair shot and everybody should do their fair share and everybody should play by the same rules
column6: because that's how our economy's grown. That's how we built the world's greatest middle class.  And -- and that is part of what's at stake in this election. There's a fundamentally different vision about how we move our country forward.  I believe Governor Romney is a good man. Loves his family
column7: cares about his faith. But I also believe that when he said behind closed doors that 47 percent of the country considered themselves victims who refuse personal responsibility
column8: think about who he was talking about.  Folks on Social Security who've worked all their lives. Veterans who've sacrificed for this country. Students who are out there trying to hopefully advance their own dreams
column9: but also this country's dreams. Soldiers who are overseas fighting for us right now. People who are working hard every day
column10: paying payroll tax
column11: gas taxes
column12: but don't make enough income.  And I want to fight for them. That's what I've been doing for the last four years. Because if they succeed
column13: I believe the country succeeds.  When my grandfather fought in World War II and he came back and he got a G.I. Bill and that allowed him to go to college
column14: that wasn't a handout. That was something that advanced the entire country. And I want to make sure that the next generation has those same opportunities. That's why I'm asking for your vote and that's why I'm asking for another four years.

column1: I care about 100 percent of the American people. I want 100 percent of the American people to have a bright and prosperous future. column14: that wasn't a handout. That was something that advanced the entire country. And I want to make sure that the next generation has those same opportunities. That's why I'm asking for your vote and that's why I'm asking for another four years.

column2: '16Oct'
column3: 11)	" Barry? Where is Barry?

column1: Thank you
column2: and that's an opportunity for me
column3: and I appreciate it. In the nature of a campaign
column4: it seems that some campaigns are focused on attacking a person rather than prescribing their own future and the things they'd like to do. In the course of that
column5: I think the president's campaign has tried to characterize me as -- as someone who's very different than who I am.  I care about 100 percent of the American people. I want 100 percent of the American people to have a bright and prosperous future. I care about our kids. I understand what it takes to make a bright and prosperous future for America again. I spent my life in the private sector
column6: not in government. I'm a guy who wants to help with the experience I have
column7: the American people.  My -- my passion probably flows from the fact that I believe in God. And I believe we're all children of the same God. I believe we have a responsibility to care for one another. I -- I served as a missionary for my church. I served as a pastor in my congregation for about 10 years. I've sat across the table from people who were out of work and worked with them to try and find new work or to help them through tough times.  I went to the Olympics when they were in trouble to try and get them on track. And as governor of my state
column8: I was able to get 100 percent of my people insured
column9: all my kids
column10: about 98 percent of the adults. I was able also to get our schools ranked number one in the nation
column11: so 100 percent of our kids would have a bright opportunity for a future.

column1: I understand that I can get this country on track again. We don't have to settle for what we're going through. We don't have to settle for gasoline at four bucks. We don't have to settle for unemployment at a chronically high level. We don't have to settle for 47 million people on food stamps. We don't have to settle for 50 percent of kids coming out of college not able to get work. We don't have to settle for 23 million people struggling to find a good job. If I become president
column2: I'll get America working again. I will get us on track to a balanced budget. The president hasn't. I will. I'll make sure we can reform Medicare and Social Security to preserve them for coming -- coming generations. The president said he would. He didn't.

column1: I'll get our incomes up. And by the way
column2: I've done these things. I served as governor and showed I could get them done.

column1: Barry
column2: I think a lot of this campaign
column3: maybe over the last four years
column4: has been devoted to this nation that I think government creates jobs
column5: that that somehow is the answer. That's not what I believe. I believe that the free enterprise system is the greatest engine of prosperity the world's ever known.  I believe in self-reliance and individual initiative and risk takers being rewarded. But I also believe that everybody should have a fair shot and everybody should do their fair share and everybody should play by the same rules
column6: because that's how our economy's grown. That's how we built the world's greatest middle class.  And -- and that is part of what's at stake in this election. There's a fundamentally different vision about how we move our country forward.  I believe Governor Romney is a good man. Loves his family
column7: cares about his faith. But I also believe that when he said behind closed doors that 47 percent of the country considered themselves victims who refuse personal responsibility
column8: think about who he was talking about.  Folks on Social Security who've worked all their lives. Veterans who've sacrificed for this country. Students who are out there trying to hopefully advance their own dreams
column9: but also this country's dreams. Soldiers who are overseas fighting for us right now. People who are working hard every day
column10: paying payroll tax
column11: gas taxes
column12: but don't make enough income.  And I want to fight for them. That's what I've been doing for the last four years. Because if they succeed
column13: I believe the country succeeds.  When my grandfather fought in World War II and he came back and he got a G.I. Bill and that allowed him to go to college
column14: that wasn't a handout. That was something that advanced the entire country. And I want to make sure that the next generation has those same opportunities. That's why I'm asking for your vote and that's why I'm asking for another four years.

We don't have to settle for unemployment at a chronically high level. We don't have to settle for 47 million people on food stamps. We don't have to settle for 50 percent of kids coming out of college not able to get work. We don't have to settle for 23 million people struggling to find a good job. If I become president
column2: I'll get America working again. I will get us on track to a balanced budget. The president hasn't. I will. I'll make sure we can reform Medicare and Social Security to preserve them for coming -- coming generations. The president said he would. He didn't.

column1: I'll get our incomes up. And by the way
column2: I've done these things. I served as governor and showed I could get them done.

column1: Barry
column2: I think a lot of this campaign
column3: maybe over the last four years
column4: has been devoted to this nation that I think government creates jobs
column5: that that somehow is the answer. That's not what I believe. I believe that the free enterprise system is the greatest engine of prosperity the world's ever known.  I believe in self-reliance and individual initiative and risk takers being rewarded. But I also believe that everybody should have a fair shot and everybody should do their fair share and everybody should play by the same rules
column6: because that's how our economy's grown. That's how we built the world's greatest middle class.  And -- and that is part of what's at stake in this election. There's a fundamentally different vision about how we move our country forward.  I believe Governor Romney is a good man. Loves his family
column7: cares about his faith. But I also believe that when he said behind closed doors that 47 percent of the country considered themselves victims who refuse personal responsibility
column8: think about who he was talking about.  Folks on Social Security who've worked all their lives. Veterans who've sacrificed for this country. Students who are out there trying to hopefully advance their own dreams
column9: but also this country's dreams. Soldiers who are overseas fighting for us right now. People who are working hard every day
column10: paying payroll tax
column11: gas taxes
column12: but don't make enough income.  And I want to fight for them. That's what I've been doing for the last four years. Because if they succeed
column13: I believe the country succeeds.  When my grandfather fought in World War II and he came back and he got a G.I. Bill and that allowed him to go to college
column14: that wasn't a handout. That was something that advanced the entire country. And I want to make sure that the next generation has those same opportunities. That's why I'm asking for your vote and that's why I'm asking for another four years.

column3: 3)	" Hi
column4: Mary.

column1: You're doing great.
Thank you very much. And let me tell you
column2: you're absolutely right about part of that
column3: which is I want to bring the rates down
column4: I want to simplify the tax code
column5: and I want to get middle- income taxpayers to have lower taxes. And the reason I want middle-income taxpayers to have lower taxes is because middle-income taxpayers have been buried over the past four years. You've seen
column6: as middle-income people in this country
column7: incomes go down $4
column8: 300 a family
column9: even as gasoline prices have gone up $2
column10: 000. Health insurance premiums
column11: up $2
column12: 500. Food prices up. Utility prices up.  The middle-income families in America have been crushed over the last four years. So I want to get some relief to middle-income families. That's part -- that's part one.  Now
column13: how about deductions? 'Cause I'm going to bring rates down across the board for everybody
column14: but I'm going to limit deductions and exemptions and credits
column15: particularly for people at the high end
column16: because I am not going to have people at the high end pay less than they're paying now.  The top 5 percent of taxpayers will continue to pay 60 percent of the income tax the nation collects. So that'll stay the same.  Middle-income people are going to get a tax break.  And so
column17: in terms of bringing down deductions
column18: one way of doing that would be say everybody gets -- I'll pick a number -- $25
column19: 000 of deductions and credits
column20: and you can decide which ones to use. Your home mortgage interest deduction
column22: child tax credit
column23: and so forth
column24: you can use those as part of filling that bucket
column25: if you will
column26: of deductions.  But your rate comes down and the burden also comes down on you for one more reason
column27: and that is every middle-income taxpayer no longer will pay any tax on interest
column28: dividends or capital gains. No tax on your savings. That makes life a lot easier.  If you're getting interest from a bank
column29: if you're getting a statement from a mutual fund or any other kind of investment you have
column30: you don't have to worry about filing taxes on that
column31: because there'll be no taxes for anybody making $200
column32: 000.00 per year and less
column33: on your interest
column34: dividends and capital gains. Why am I lowering taxes on the middle-class? Because under the last four years
column35: they've been buried. And I want to help people in the middle-class.  And I will not -- I will not under any circumstances
column36: reduce the share that's being paid by the highest income taxpayers. And I will not
column37: under any circumstances increase taxes on the middle-class. The president's spending
column38: the president's borrowing will cost this nation to have to raise taxes on the American people. Not just at the high end. A recent study has shown the people in the middle-class will see $4
column39: 000.00 per year in higher taxes as a result of the spending and borrowing of this administration.  I will not let that happen. I want to get us on track to a balanced budget
column40: and I'm going to reduce the tax burden on middle income families. And what's that going to do? It's going to help those families
column41: and it's going to create incentives to start growing jobs again in this country.

column1: My philosophy on taxes has been simple. And that is
column2: I want to give middle-class families and folks who are striving to get into the middle-class some relief. Because they have been hit hard over the last decade. Over the last 15
column3: over the last 20 years. So four years ago I stood on a stage just like this one. Actually it was a town hall
column4: and I said I would cut taxes for middle- class families
column5: and that's what I've done
column6: by $3
column7: 600.00. I said I would cut taxes for small businesses
column8: who are the drivers and engines of growth. And we've cut them 18 times. And I want to continue those tax cuts for middle-class families
column9: and for small business.  But what I've also said is
column10: if we're serious about reducing the deficit
column11: if this is genuinely a moral obligation to the next generation
column12: then in addition to some tough spending cuts
column13: we've also got to make sure that the wealthy do a little bit more.  So what I've said is
column14: your first $250
column15: 000.00 worth of income
column16: no change. And that means 98 percent of American families
column17: 97 percent of small businesses
column18: they will not see a tax increase. I'm ready to sign that bill right now. The only reason it's not happening is because Governor Romney's allies in Congress have held the 98 percent hostage because they want tax breaks for the top 2 percent.  But what I've also says is for above $250
column20: we can go back to the tax rates we had when Bill Clinton was president. We created 23 million new jobs. That's part of what took us from deficits to surplus. It will be good for our economy and it will be good for job creation.  Now
column21: Governor Romney has a different philosophy. He was on 60 Minutes just two weeks ago and he was asked: Is it fair for somebody like you
column22: making $20 million a year
column23: to pay a lower tax rate than a nurse or a bus driver
column24: somebody making $50
column25: 000 year? And he said
column26: ""Yes
column27: I think that's fair."" Not only that
column28: he said
column29: ""I think that's what grows the economy.""  Well
column30: I fundamentally disagree with that. I think what grows the economy is when you get that tax credit that we put in place for your kids going to college. I think that grows the economy. I think what grows the economy is when we make sure small businesses are getting a tax credit for hiring veterans who fought for our country. That grows our economy.  So we just have a different theory. And when Governor Romney stands here
column31: after a year of campaigning
column32: when during a Republican primary he stood on stage and said ""I'm going to give tax cuts"" -- he didn't say tax rate cuts
column33: he said ""tax cuts to everybody
column34: including the top 1 percent
column35: you should believe him because that's been his history.  And that's exactly the kind of top-down economics that is not going to work if we want a strong middle class and an economy that's striving for everybody.

column1: You're absolutely right. You heard what I said about my tax plan. The top 5 percent will continue to pay 60 percent
column2: as they do today. I'm not looking to cut taxes for wealthy people. I am looking to cut taxes for middle-income people.  And why do I want to bring rates down
column3: and at the same time lower exemptions and deductions
column4: particularly for people at the high end? Because if you bring rates down
column5: it makes it easier for small business to keep more of their capital and hire people.  And for me
column6: this is about jobs. I want to get America's economy going again. Fifty-four percent of America's workers work in businesses that are taxed as individuals. So when you bring those rates down
column7: those small businesses are able to keep more money and hire more people.  For me
column8: I look at what's happened in the last four years and say this has been a disappointment. We can do better than this. We don't have to settle for
column9: how many months
column10: 43 months with unemployment above 8 percent
column11: 23 million Americans struggling to find a good job right now.  There are 3.5 million more women living in poverty today than when the president took office.  We don't have to live like this. We can get this economy going again. My five-point plan does it. Energy independence for North America in five years. Opening up more trade
column12: particularly in Latin America. Cracking down on China when they cheat. Getting us to a balanced budget. Fixing our training programs for our workers. And finally
column13: championing small business.  I want to make small businesses grow and thrive. I know how to make that happen. I spent my life in the private sector. I know why jobs come and why they go. And they're going now because of the policies of this administration.

column1: No
column2: it's not settled. Look
column3: the cost of lowering rates for everybody across the board
column4: 20 percent. Along with what he also wants to do in terms of eliminating the estate tax
column5: along what he wants to do in terms of corporates
column6: changes in the tax code
column7: it costs about $5 trillion.  Governor Romney then also wants to spend $2 trillion on additional military programs even though the military's not asking for them. That's $7 trillion.  He also wants to continue the Bush tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans. That's another trillion dollars -- that's $8 trillion.  Now
column8: what he says is he's going to make sure that this doesn't add to the deficit and he's going to cut middleclass taxes.  But when he's asked
column9: how are you going to do it
column10: which deductions
column11: which loopholes are you going to close? He can't tell you.  The -- the fact that he only has to pay 14 percent on his taxes when a lot of you are paying much higher. He's already taken that off the board
column12: capital gains are going to continue to be at a low rate so we -- we're not going to get money that way.  We haven't heard from the governor any specifics beyond Big Bird and eliminating funding for Planned Parenthood in terms of how he pays for that.  Now
column13: Governor Romney was a very successful investor. If somebody came to you
column14: Governor
column15: with a plan that said
column16: here
column17: I want to spend $7 or $8 trillion
column18: and then we're going to pay for it
column19: but we can't tell you until maybe after the election how we're going to do it
column20: you wouldn't take such a sketchy deal and neither should you
column22: because the math doesn't add up.  And -- and what's at stake here is one of two things
column23: either Candy -- this blows up the deficit because keep in mind
column24: this is just to pay for the additional spending that he's talking about
column25: $7 trillion - $8 trillion before we even get to the deficit we already have. Or
column26: alternatively
column27: it's got to be paid for
column28: not only by closing deductions for wealthy individuals
column29: that -- that will pay for about 4 percent reduction in tax rates.  You're going to be paying for it. You're going to lose some deductions
column30: and you can't buy the sales pitch. Nobody who's looked at it that's serious
column31: actually believes it adds up.

column1: Well of course they add up. I -- I was -- I was someone who ran businesses for 25 years
column2: and balanced the budget. I ran the Olympics and balanced the budget. I ran the -- the state of Massachusetts as a governor
column3: to the extent any governor does
column4: and balanced the budget all four years. When we're talking about math that doesn't add up
column5: how about $4 trillion of deficits over the last four years
column6: $5 trillion? That's math that doesn't add up. We have -- we have a president talking about someone's plan in a way that's completely foreign to what my real plan is.

column1: And then we have his own record
column2: which is we have four consecutive years where he said when he was running for office
column3: he would cut the deficit in half. Instead he's doubled it. We've gone from $10 trillion of national debt
column4: to $16 trillion of national debt. If the president were reelected
column5: we'd go to almost $20 trillion of national debt. This puts us on a road to Greece. I know what it takes to balance budgets. I've done it my entire life. So for instance when he says
column6: ""Yours is a $5 trillion cut."" Well
column7: no it's not. Because I'm offsetting some of the reductions with holding down some of the deductions. And...

column1: And I just described -- I just described to you
column2: Mr. President -- I just described to you precisely how I'd do it which is with a single number that people can put -- and they can put they're -- they're deductions and credits... (CROSSTALK)

column4: Mary.

column1: You're doing great.
Thank you very much. And let me tell you
column2: you're absolutely right about part of that
column3: which is I want to bring the rates down
column4: I want to simplify the tax code
column5: and I want to get middle- income taxpayers to have lower taxes. And the reason I want middle-income taxpayers to have lower taxes is because middle-income taxpayers have been buried over the past four years. You've seen
column6: as middle-income people in this country
column7: incomes go down $4
column8: 300 a family
column9: even as gasoline prices have gone up $2
column10: 000. Health insurance premiums
column11: up $2
column12: 500. Food prices up. Utility prices up.  The middle-income families in America have been crushed over the last four years. So I want to get some relief to middle-income families. That's part -- that's part one.  Now
column13: how about deductions? 'Cause I'm going to bring rates down across the board for everybody
column14: but I'm going to limit deductions and exemptions and credits
column15: particularly for people at the high end
column16: because I am not going to have people at the high end pay less than they're paying now.  The top 5 percent of taxpayers will continue to pay 60 percent of the income tax the nation collects. So that'll stay the same.  Middle-income people are going to get a tax break.  And so
column17: in terms of bringing down deductions
column18: one way of doing that would be say everybody gets -- I'll pick a number -- $25
column19: 000 of deductions and credits
column20: and you can decide which ones to use. Your home mortgage interest deduction
column22: child tax credit
column23: and so forth
column24: you can use those as part of filling that bucket
column25: if you will
column26: of deductions.  But your rate comes down and the burden also comes down on you for one more reason
column27: and that is every middle-income taxpayer no longer will pay any tax on interest
column28: dividends or capital gains. No tax on your savings. That makes life a lot easier.  If you're getting interest from a bank
column29: if you're getting a statement from a mutual fund or any other kind of investment you have
column30: you don't have to worry about filing taxes on that
column31: because there'll be no taxes for anybody making $200
column32: 000.00 per year and less
column33: on your interest
column34: dividends and capital gains. Why am I lowering taxes on the middle-class? Because under the last four years
column35: they've been buried. And I want to help people in the middle-class.  And I will not -- I will not under any circumstances
column36: reduce the share that's being paid by the highest income taxpayers. And I will not
column37: under any circumstances increase taxes on the middle-class. The president's spending
column38: the president's borrowing will cost this nation to have to raise taxes on the American people. Not just at the high end. A recent study has shown the people in the middle-class will see $4
column39: 000.00 per year in higher taxes as a result of the spending and borrowing of this administration.  I will not let that happen. I want to get us on track to a balanced budget
column40: and I'm going to reduce the tax burden on middle income families. And what's that going to do? It's going to help those families
column41: and it's going to create incentives to start growing jobs again in this country.

column1: My philosophy on taxes has been simple. And that is
column2: I want to give middle-class families and folks who are striving to get into the middle-class some relief. Because they have been hit hard over the last decade. Over the last 15
column3: over the last 20 years. So four years ago I stood on a stage just like this one. Actually it was a town hall
column4: and I said I would cut taxes for middle- class families
column5: and that's what I've done
column6: by $3
column7: 600.00. I said I would cut taxes for small businesses
column8: who are the drivers and engines of growth. And we've cut them 18 times. And I want to continue those tax cuts for middle-class families
column9: and for small business.  But what I've also said is
column10: if we're serious about reducing the deficit
column11: if this is genuinely a moral obligation to the next generation
column12: then in addition to some tough spending cuts
column13: we've also got to make sure that the wealthy do a little bit more.  So what I've said is
column14: your first $250
column15: 000.00 worth of income
column16: no change. And that means 98 percent of American families
column17: 97 percent of small businesses
column18: they will not see a tax increase. I'm ready to sign that bill right now. The only reason it's not happening is because Governor Romney's allies in Congress have held the 98 percent hostage because they want tax breaks for the top 2 percent.  But what I've also says is for above $250
column20: we can go back to the tax rates we had when Bill Clinton was president. We created 23 million new jobs. That's part of what took us from deficits to surplus. It will be good for our economy and it will be good for job creation.  Now
column21: Governor Romney has a different philosophy. He was on 60 Minutes just two weeks ago and he was asked: Is it fair for somebody like you

column24: somebody making $50
column25: 000 year? And he said
column26: ""Yes

column28: he said
column29: ""I think that's what grows the economy.""  Well
column30: I fundamentally disagree with that. I think what grows the economy is when you get that tax credit that we put in place for your kids going to college. I think that grows the economy. I think what grows the economy is when we make sure small businesses are getting a tax credit for hiring veterans who fought for our country. That grows our economy.  So we just have a different theory. And when Governor Romney stands here

column33: he said ""tax cuts to everybody
column34: including the top 1 percent
column35: you should believe him because that's been his history.  And that's exactly the kind of top-down economics that is not going to work if we want a strong middle class and an economy that's striving for everybody.

column1: You're absolutely right. You heard what I said about my tax plan. The top 5 percent will continue to pay 60 percent
column2: as they do today. I'm not looking to cut taxes for wealthy people. I am looking to cut taxes for middle-income people.  And why do I want to bring rates down
column3: and at the same time lower exemptions and deductions
column4: particularly for people at the high end? Because if you bring rates down
column5: it makes it easier for small business to keep more of their capital and hire people.  And for me
column6: this is about jobs. I want to get America's economy going again. Fifty-four percent of America's workers work in businesses that are taxed as individuals. So when you bring those rates down
column7: those small businesses are able to keep more money and hire more people.  For me
column8: I look at what's happened in the last four years and say this has been a disappointment. We can do better than this. We don't have to settle for
column9: how many months
column10: 43 months with unemployment above 8 percent
column11: 23 million Americans struggling to find a good job right now.  There are 3.5 million more women living in poverty today than when the president took office.  We don't have to live like this. We can get this economy going again. My five-point plan does it. Energy independence for North America in five years. Opening up more trade
column12: particularly in Latin America. Cracking down on China when they cheat. Getting us to a balanced budget. Fixing our training programs for our workers. And finally
column13: championing small business.  I want to make small businesses grow and thrive. I know how to make that happen. I spent my life in the private sector. I know why jobs come and why they go. And they're going now because of the policies of this administration.

column1: No
column2: it's not settled. Look
column3: the cost of lowering rates for everybody across the board
column4: 20 percent. Along with what he also wants to do in terms of eliminating the estate tax
column5: along what he wants to do in terms of corporates
column6: changes in the tax code
column7: it costs about $5 trillion.  Governor Romney then also wants to spend $2 trillion on additional military programs even though the military's not asking for them. That's $7 trillion.  He also wants to continue the Bush tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans. That's another trillion dollars -- that's $8 trillion.  Now
column8: what he says is he's going to make sure that this doesn't add to the deficit and he's going to cut middleclass taxes.  But when he's asked
column9: how are you going to do it
column10: which deductions
column11: which loopholes are you going to close? He can't tell you.  The -- the fact that he only has to pay 14 percent on his taxes when a lot of you are paying much higher. He's already taken that off the board
column12: capital gains are going to continue to be at a low rate so we -- we're not going to get money that way.  We haven't heard from the governor any specifics beyond Big Bird and eliminating funding for Planned Parenthood in terms of how he pays for that.  Now
column13: Governor Romney was a very successful investor. If somebody came to you
column14: Governor
column15: with a plan that said
column16: here
column17: I want to spend $7 or $8 trillion
column18: and then we're going to pay for it
column19: but we can't tell you until maybe after the election how we're going to do it
column20: you wouldn't take such a sketchy deal and neither should you
column22: because the math doesn't add up.  And -- and what's at stake here is one of two things
column23: either Candy -- this blows up the deficit because keep in mind
column24: this is just to pay for the additional spending that he's talking about
column25: $7 trillion - $8 trillion before we even get to the deficit we already have. Or
column26: alternatively
column27: it's got to be paid for
column28: not only by closing deductions for wealthy individuals
column29: that -- that will pay for about 4 percent reduction in tax rates.  You're going to be paying for it. You're going to lose some deductions
column30: and you can't buy the sales pitch. Nobody who's looked at it that's serious
column31: actually believes it adds up.

column1: Well of course they add up. I -- I was -- I was someone who ran businesses for 25 years
column2: and balanced the budget. I ran the Olympics and balanced the budget. I ran the -- the state of Massachusetts as a governor
column3: to the extent any governor does
column4: and balanced the budget all four years. When we're talking about math that doesn't add up
column5: how about $4 trillion of deficits over the last four years
column6: $5 trillion? That's math that doesn't add up. We have -- we have a president talking about someone's plan in a way that's completely foreign to what my real plan is.

column1: And then we have his own record
column2: which is we have four consecutive years where he said when he was running for office
column3: he would cut the deficit in half. Instead he's doubled it. We've gone from $10 trillion of national debt
column4: to $16 trillion of national debt. If the president were reelected
column5: we'd go to almost $20 trillion of national debt. This puts us on a road to Greece. I know what it takes to balance budgets. I've done it my entire life. So for instance when he says
column6: ""Yours is a $5 trillion cut."" Well
column7: no it's not. Because I'm offsetting some of the reductions with holding down some of the deductions. And...

column1: And I just described -- I just described to you
column2: Mr. President -- I just described to you precisely how I'd do it which is with a single number that people can put -- and they can put they're -- they're deductions and credits... (CROSSTALK)

column185: the cost of lowering rates for everybody across the board
column187: 'Along with what he also wants to do in terms of eliminating the estate tax
column188: along what he wants to do in terms of corporates
column191: ""Governor Romney then also wants to spend $2 trillion on additional military programs even though the military's not asking for them.""
column193: 'He also wants to continue the Bush tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans.'
column196: what he says is he's going to make sure that this doesn't add to the deficit and he's going to cut middleclass taxes.""
column198: how are you going to do it
column200: which loopholes are you going to close?""
column202: 'The -- the fact that he only has to pay 14 percent on his taxes when a lot of you are paying much higher.'
column203: ""He's already taken that off the board
column204: capital gains are going to continue to be at a low rate so we -- we're not going to get money that way.""
column205: ""We haven't heard from the governor any specifics beyond Big Bird and eliminating funding for Planned Parenthood in terms of how he pays for that.""
column207: Governor Romney was a very successful investor.'
column212: I want to spend $7 or $8 trillion
column213: and then we're going to pay for it
column214: but we can't tell you until maybe after the election how we're going to do it
column215: you wouldn't take such a sketchy deal and neither should you
column217: because the math doesn't add up.""
column218: ""And -- and what's at stake here is one of two things
column219: either Candy -- this blows up the deficit because keep in mind
column220: this is just to pay for the additional spending that he's talking about
column221: $7 trillion - $8 trillion before we even get to the deficit we already have.""
column224: it's got to be paid for
column225: not only by closing deductions for wealthy individuals
column226: that -- that will pay for about 4 percent reduction in tax rates.""
column227: ""You're going to be paying for it.""
column229: and you can't buy the sales pitch.""
column230: ""Nobody who's looked at it that's serious
column234: 'I -- I was -- I was someone who ran businesses for 25 years
column236: 'I ran the Olympics and balanced the budget.'
column237: 'I ran the -- the state of Massachusetts as a governor
column238: to the extent any governor does
column239: and balanced the budget all four years.'
column240: ""When we're talking about math that doesn't add up
column241: how about $4 trillion of deficits over the last four years
column244: ""We have -- we have a president talking about someone's plan in a way that's completely foreign to what my real plan is.""
column245: 'And then we have his own record

column247: he would cut the deficit in half.'

column253: 'This puts us on a road to Greece.'
