column1: The middle class is getting crushed under the policies of a president who has not understood what it takes to get the economy working again. He keeps saying
column2: ""Look
column3: I've created 5 million jobs."" That's after losing 5 million jobs. The entire record is such that the unemployment has not been reduced in this country. The unemployment
column4: the number of people who are still looking for work
column5: is still 23 million Americans. There are more people in poverty
column6: one out of six people in poverty.  How about food stamps? When he took office
column7: 32 million people were on food stamps. Today
column8: 47 million people are on food stamps. How about the growth of the economy? It's growing more slowly this year than last year
column9: and more slowly last year than the year before.  The president wants to do well. I understand. But the policies he's put in place from Obamacare to Dodd-Frank to his tax policies to his regulatory policies
column10: these policies combined have not let this economy take off and grow like it could have.  You might say
column11: ""Well
column12: you got an example of one that worked better?"" Yeah
column13: in the Reagan recession where unemployment hit 10.8 percent
column14: between that period -- the end of that recession and the equivalent of time to today
column15: Ronald Reagan's recovery created twice as many jobs as this president's recovery. Five million jobs doesn't even keep up with our population growth. And the only reason the unemployment rate seems a little lower today is because of all the people that have dropped out of the workforce.  The president has tried
column16: but his policies haven't worked. He's great as a -- as a -- as a speaker and describing his plans and his vision. That's wonderful
column17: except we have a record to look at. And that record shows he just hasn't been able to cut the deficit
column18: to put in place reforms for Medicare and Social Security to preserve them
column19: to get us the rising incomes we need. Median income is down $4
column20: 300 a family and 23 million Americans out of work. That's what this election is about. It's about who can get the middle class in this country a bright and prosperous future and assure our kids the kind of hope and optimism they deserve.

column1: I said that we would put in place health care reform to make sure that insurance companies can't jerk you around and if you don't have health insurance

column3: 6)	" Well
column4: we've gone through a tough four years. There's no doubt about it. But four years ago
column5: I told the American people and I told you I would cut taxes for middle class families. And I did. I told you I'd cut taxes for small businesses
column6: and I have. I said that I'd end the war in Iraq
column7: and I did. I said we'd refocus attention on those who actually attacked us on 9/11
column8: and we have gone after Al Qaeda's leadership like never before and Osama bin Laden is dead.

column1: I said that we would put in place health care reform to make sure that insurance companies can't jerk you around and if you don't have health insurance
column2: that you'd have a chance to get affordable insurance
column3: and I have. I committed that I would rein in the excesses of Wall Street
column4: and we passed the toughest Wall Street reforms since the 1930s. We've created five million jobs
column5: and gone from 800 jobs a month being lost
column6: and we are making progress. We saved an auto industry that was on the brink of collapse.  Now
column7: does that mean you're not struggling? Absolutely not. A lot of us are. And that's why the plan that I've put forward for manufacturing and education
column8: and reducing our deficit in a sensible way
column9: using the savings from ending wars
column10: to rebuild America and putting people back to work. Making sure that we are controlling our own energy
column11: but not only the energy of today
column12: but also the energy of the future. All of those things will make a difference
column13: so the point is the commitments I've made
column14: I've kept.  And those that I haven't been able to keep
column15: it's not for lack of trying and we're going to get it done in a second term. But
column16: you should pay attention to this campaign
column17: because Governor Romney has made some commitments as well. And I suspect he'll keep those too. You know when members of the Republican Congress say
column18: ""We're going to sign a no tax pledge
column19: so that we don't ask a dime for millionaires and billionaires to reduce our deficit so we can still invest in education
column20: and helping kids go to college. He said
column22: ""We're going to cut Planned Parenthood funding."" He said
column23: ""Me too."" When he said
column24: ""We're going to repeal Obamacare. First thing I'm going to do
column25: despite the fact that it's the same health care plan that he passed in Massachusetts and is working well. He said
column26: ""Me too."" That is not the kind of leadership that you need
column27: but you should expect that those are promises he's going to keep.  (CROSSTALK)

column1: ...the choice in this election is going to be whose promises are going to be more likely to help you in your life? Make sure your kids can go to college. Make sure that you are getting a good paying job
column2: making sure that Medicare and Social Security... (CROSSTALK)

column1: ...will be there for you.

I think you know better. I think you know that these last four years haven't been so good as the president just described and that you don't feel like your confident that the next four years are going to be much better either. I can tell you that if you were to elect President Obama
column2: you know what you're going to get. You're going to get a repeat of the last four years. We just can't afford four more years like the last four years.  He said that by now we'd have unemployment at 5.4 percent. The difference between where it is and 5.4 percent is 9 million Americans without work.  I wasn't the one that said 5.4 percent. This was the president's plan. Didn't get there.  He said he would have by now put forward a plan to reform Medicare and Social Security
column3: because he pointed out they're on the road to bankruptcy. He would reform them. He'd get that done. He hasn't even made a proposal on either one.  He said in his first year he'd put out an immigration plan that would deal with our immigration challenges. Didn't even file it.  This is a president who has not been able to do what he said he'd do. He said that he'd cut in half the deficit. He hasn't done that either. In fact
column4: he doubled it. He said that by now middle-income families would have a reduction in their health insurance premiums by $2
column5: 500 a year. It's gone up by $2
column6: 500 a year. And if Obamacare is passed
column7: or implemented -- it's already been passed -- if it's implemented fully
column8: it'll be another $2
column9: 500 on top.

column1: The middle class is getting crushed under the policies of a president who has not understood what it takes to get the economy working again. He keeps saying
column2: ""Look
column3: I've created 5 million jobs."" That's after losing 5 million jobs. The entire record is such that the unemployment has not been reduced in this country. The unemployment
column4: the number of people who are still looking for work
column5: is still 23 million Americans. There are more people in poverty
column6: one out of six people in poverty.  How about food stamps? When he took office
column7: 32 million people were on food stamps. Today
column8: 47 million people are on food stamps. How about the growth of the economy? It's growing more slowly this year than last year
column9: and more slowly last year than the year before.  The president wants to do well. I understand. But the policies he's put in place from Obamacare to Dodd-Frank to his tax policies to his regulatory policies
column10: these policies combined have not let this economy take off and grow like it could have.  You might say
column11: ""Well
column12: you got an example of one that worked better?"" Yeah
column13: in the Reagan recession where unemployment hit 10.8 percent
column14: between that period -- the end of that recession and the equivalent of time to today
column15: Ronald Reagan's recovery created twice as many jobs as this president's recovery. Five million jobs doesn't even keep up with our population growth. And the only reason the unemployment rate seems a little lower today is because of all the people that have dropped out of the workforce.  The president has tried
column16: but his policies haven't worked. He's great as a -- as a -- as a speaker and describing his plans and his vision. That's wonderful
column17: except we have a record to look at. And that record shows he just hasn't been able to cut the deficit
column18: to put in place reforms for Medicare and Social Security to preserve them
column19: to get us the rising incomes we need. Median income is down $4
column20: 300 a family and 23 million Americans out of work. That's what this election is about. It's about who can get the middle class in this country a bright and prosperous future and assure our kids the kind of hope and optimism they deserve.

column1: Is it Loraina?
Lorraine?
Lorraine.

column2: thanks.

column1: Thank you. Lorraine? Did I get that right? Good. Thank you for your question. And let me step back and tell you what I would like to do with our immigration policy broadly and include an answer to your question. But first of all
column2: this is a nation of immigrants. We welcome people coming to this country as immigrants. My dad was born in Mexico of American parents; Ann's dad was born in Wales and is a first-generation American. We welcome legal immigrants into this country.  I want our legal system to work better. I want it to be streamlined. I want it to be clearer. I don't think you have to -- shouldn't have to hire a lawyer to figure out how to get into this country legally. I also think that we should give visas to people -- green cards
column3: rather
column4: to people who graduate with skills that we need. People around the world with accredited degrees in science and math get a green card stapled to their diploma
column5: come to the U.S. of A. We should make sure our legal system works.  Number two
column6: we're going to have to stop illegal immigration. There are 4 million people who are waiting in line to get here legally. Those who've come here illegally take their place. So I will not grant amnesty to those who have come here illegally.  What I will do is I'll put in place an employment verification system and make sure that employers that hire people who have come here illegally are sanctioned for doing so. I won't put in place magnets for people coming here illegally. So for instance
column7: I would not give driver's licenses to those that have come here illegally as the president would.  The kids of those that came here illegally
column8: those kids
column9: I think
column10: should have a pathway to become a permanent resident of the United States and military service
column11: for instance
column12: is one way they would have that kind of pathway to become a permanent resident.

column1: Now when the president ran for office
column2: he said that he'd put in place
column3: in his first year
column4: a piece of legislation -- he'd file a bill in his first year that would reform our -- our immigration system
column5: protect legal immigration
column6: stop illegal immigration. He didn't do it. He had a Democrat House
column7: a Democrat Senate
column8: super majority in both Houses. Why did he fail to even promote legislation that would have provided an answer for those that want to come legally and for those that are here illegally today? What's a question I think the -- the president will have a chance to answer right now.

column1: Good
column2: I look forward to it. Was -- Lorranna -- Lorraine -- we are a nation of immigrants. I mean we're just a few miles away from Ellis Island. We all understand what this country has become because talent from all around the world wants to come here. People are willing to take risks. People who want to build on their dreams and make sure their kids have an even bigger dreams than they have.  But we're also a nation of laws. So what I've said is we need to fix a broken immigration system and I've done everything that I can on my own and sought cooperation from Congress to make sure that we fix the system.  The first thing we did was to streamline the legal immigration system
column3: to reduce the backlog
column4: make it easier
column5: simpler and cheaper for people who are waiting in line
column6: obeying the law to make sure that they can come here and contribute to our country and that's good for our economic growth.  They'll start new businesses. They'll make things happen to create jobs here in the United States.  Number two
column7: we do have to deal with our border so we put more border patrol on the -- any time in history and the flow of undocumented works across the border is actually lower than it's been in 40 years.  What I've also said is if we're going to go after folks who are here illegally
column8: we should do it smartly and go after folks who are criminals
column9: gang bangers
column10: people who are hurting the community
column11: not after students
column12: not after folks who are here just because they're trying to figure out how to feed their families. And that's what we've done. And what I've also said is for young people who come here
column13: brought here often times by their parents. Had gone to school here
column14: pledged allegiance to the flag. Think of this as their country. Understand themselves as Americans in every way except having papers. And we should make sure that we give them a pathway to citizenship.  And that's what I've done administratively. Now
column15: Governor Romney just said
column16: you know he wants to help those young people too
column17: but during the Republican primary
column18: he said
column19: ""I will veto the DREAM Act""
column20: that would allow these young people to have access."" His main strategy during the Republican primary was to say
column21: ""We're going to encourage self-deportation."" Making life so miserable on folks that they'll leave. He called the Arizona law a model for the nation. Part of the Arizona law said that law enforcement officers could stop folks because they suspected maybe they looked like they might be undocumented workers and check their papers.  You know what? If my daughter or yours looks to somebody like they're not a citizen
column22: I don't want -- I don't want to empower somebody like that. So
column23: we can fix this system in a comprehensive way. And when Governor Romney says
column24: the challenge is
column25: ""Well Obama didn't try."" That's not true. I have sat down with Democrats and Republicans at the beginning of my term. And I said
column26: let's fix this system. Including Senators previously who had supported it on the Republican side. But it's very hard for Republican's in Congress to support comprehensive immigration reform
column27: if their standard bearer has said that
column28: this is not something I'm interested in supporting.

column1: Yes.
No
column2: let -- let -- let me go back and speak to the points that the president made and -- and -- and let's get them correct. I did not say that the Arizona law was a model for the nation in that aspect. I said that the E-Verify portion of the Arizona law
column3: which is -- which is the portion of the law which says that employers could be able to determine whether someone is here illegally or not illegally
column4: that that was a model for the nation. That's number one.  Number two
column5: I asked the president a question I think Hispanics and immigrants all over the nation have asked. He was asked this on Univision the other day. Why
column6: when you said you'd filed legislation in your first year didn't you do it? And he didn't answer. He -- he doesn't answer that question. He said the standard bearer wasn't for it.  I'm glad you thought I was a standard bearer four years ago
column7: but I wasn't.  Four years ago you said in your first year you would file legislation.  In his first year
column8: I was just getting -- licking my wounds from having been beaten by John McCain
column9: all right. I was not the standard bearer.  My -- my view is that this president should have honored his promise to do as he said.  Now
column10: let me mention one other thing
column11: and that is self-deportation says let people make their own choice. What I was saying is
column12: we're not going to round up 12 million people
column13: undocumented illegals
column14: and take them out of the nation. Instead let people make their own choice. And if they -- if they find that -- that they can't get the benefits here that they want and they can't -- and they can't find the job they want
column15: then they'll make a decision to go a place where -- where they have better opportunities.  But I'm not in favor of rounding up people and -- and -- and taking them out of this country. I am in favor
column16: as the president has said
column17: and I agree with him
column18: which is that if people have committed crimes we got to get them out of this country.

column1: Let me mention something else the president said. It was a moment ago and I didn't get a chance to
column2: when he was describing Chinese investments and so forth.

column1: Candy? Hold on a second. The...
Mr. President
column2: I'm still speaking. (CROSSTALK)

column1: Mr. President
column2: let me finish. (CROSSTALK)

column1: I've gotta continue. (CROSSTALK)
Just going to make a point. Any investments I have over the last eight years have been managed by a blind trust. And I understand they do include investments outside the United States
column2: including in -- in Chinese companies. Mr. President
column3: have you looked at your pension? Have you looked at your pension?

column1: I've got to say...
Mr. President
column2: have you looked at your pension?

column1: You know
column2: I -- I don't look at my pension. It's not as big as yours so it doesn't take as long.

column1: Well
column2: let me give you some advice.

column1: I don't check it that often.

Let me give you some advice. Look at your pension. You also have investments in Chinese companies. You also have investments outside the United States. You also have investments through a Cayman's trust. (CROSSTALK)
I thought we were talking about immigration. (CROSSTALK)
I do want to make sure that...

I do want to make sure that -- I do want to make sure that we just understand something. Governor Romney says he wasn't referring to Arizona as a model for the nation. His top adviser on immigration is the guy who designed the Arizona law
column2: the entirety of it; not E-Verify
column3: the whole thing. That's his policy. And it's a bad policy. And it won't help us grow. Look
column4: when we think about immigration
column5: we have to understand there are folks all around the world who still see America as the land of promise. And they provide us energy and they provide us innovation and they start companies like Intel and Google. And we want to encourage that.  Now
column6: we've got to make sure that we do it in a smart way and a comprehensive way
column7: and we make the legal system better. But when we make this into a divisive political issue
column8: and when we don't have bipartisan support -- I can deliver
column9: Governor
column10: a whole bunch of Democrats to get comprehensive immigration reform done
column11: and we can't...

column1: I'll get it done. I'll get it done. First year...
... we can't -- we have not seen Republicans serious about this issue at all. And it's time for them to get serious on it.
This used to be a bipartisan issue. (CROSSTALK)

column3: 8)	" OK. Hi
column4: Kerry.

column1: I'm sorry. What's your name?
Great to see you.
Ah.
Well
column2: let me first of all talk about our diplomats
column3: because they serve all around the world and do an incredible job in a very dangerous situation. And these aren't just representatives of the United States
column4: they are my representatives. I send them there
column5: oftentimes into harm's way. I know these folks and I know their families. So nobody is more concerned about their safety and security than I am. So as soon as we found out that the Benghazi consulate was being overrun
column6: I was on the phone with my national security team and I gave them three instructions.  Number one
column7: beef up our security and procedures
column8: not just in Libya
column9: but at every embassy and consulate in the region.  Number two
column10: investigate exactly what happened
column11: regardless of where the facts lead us
column12: to make sure folks are held accountable and it doesn't happen again.  And number three
column13: we are going to find out who did this and we're going to hunt them down
column14: because one of the things that I've said throughout my presidency is when folks mess with Americans
column15: we go after them.

column1: Now Governor Romney had a very different response. While we were still dealing with our diplomats being threatened
column2: Governor Romney put out a press release
column3: trying to make political points
column4: and that's not how a commander in chief operates. You don't turn national security into a political issue. Certainly not right when it's happening. And people -- not everybody agrees with some of the decisions I've made. But when it comes to our national security
column5: I mean what I say. I said I'd end the war in Libya -- in -- in Iraq
column6: and I did. I said that we'd go after al-Qaeda and bin Laden
column7: we have. I said we'd transition out of Afghanistan
column8: and start making sure that Afghans are responsible for their own security
column9: that's what I'm doing. And when it comes to this issue
column10: when I say that we are going to find out exactly what happened
column11: everybody will be held accountable. And I am ultimately responsible for what's taking place there because these are my folks
column12: and I'm the one who has to greet those coffins when they come home. You know that I mean what I say.

column1: Thank you Kerry for your question
column2: it's an important one. And -- and I -- I think the president just said correctly that the buck does stop at his desk and -- and he takes responsibility for -- for that -- for the failure in providing those security resources
column3: and -- and those terrible things may well happen from time to time. I -- I'm -- I feel very deeply sympathetic for the families of those who lost loved ones. And today there's a memorial service for one of those that was lost in this tragedy. We -- we think of their families and care for them deeply. There were other issues associated with this -- with this tragedy. There were many days that passed before we knew whether this was a spontaneous demonstration
column4: or actually whether it was a terrorist attack.

column1: And there was no demonstration involved. It was a terrorist attack and it took a long time for that to be told to the American people. Whether there was some misleading
column2: or instead whether we just didn't know what happened
column3: you have to ask yourself why didn't we know five days later when the ambassador to the United Nations went on TV to say that this was a demonstration. How could we have not known? But I find more troubling than this
column4: that on -- on the day following the assassination of the United States ambassador
column5: the first time that's happened since 1979
column6: when -- when we have four Americans killed there
column7: when apparently we didn't know what happened
column8: that the president
column9: the day after that happened
column10: flies to Las Vegas for a political fund-raiser
column11: then the next day to Colorado for another event
column12: other political event.  I think these -- these actions taken by a president and a leader have symbolic significance and perhaps even material significance in that you'd hope that during that time we could call in the people who were actually eyewitnesses. We've read their accounts now about what happened. It was very clear this was not a demonstration. This was an attack by terrorists.  And this calls into question the president's whole policy in the Middle East. Look what's happening in Syria
column13: in Egypt
column14: now in Libya. Consider the distance between ourselves and -- and Israel
column15: the president said that -- that he was going to put daylight between us and Israel.  We have Iran four years closer to a nuclear bomb. Syria -- Syria's not just a tragedy of 30
column16: 000 civilians being killed by a military
column17: but also a strategic -- strategically significant player for America.  The president's policies throughout the Middle East began with an apology tour and -- and -- and pursue a strategy of leading from behind
column18: and this strategy is unraveling before our very eyes.

column1: Secretary Clinton has done an extraordinary job. But she works for me. I'm the president and I'm always responsible
column2: and that's why nobody's more interested in finding out exactly what happened than I do. The day after the attack
column3: governor
column4: I stood in the Rose Garden and I told the American people in the world that we are going to find out exactly what happened. That this was an act of terror and I also said that we're going to hunt down those who committed this crime.  And then a few days later
column5: I was there greeting the caskets coming into Andrews Air Force Base and grieving with the families.  And the suggestion that anybody in my team
column6: whether the Secretary of State
column7: our U.N. Ambassador
column8: anybody on my team would play politics or mislead when we've lost four of our own
column9: governor
column10: is offensive. That's not what we do. That's not what I do as president
column11: that's not what I do as Commander in Chief.

column1: Yes
I -- I think interesting the president just said something which -- which is that on the day after the attack he went into the Rose Garden and said that this was an act of terror.
That's what I said.
You said in the Rose Garden the day after the attack
column2: it was an act of terror. It was not a spontaneous demonstration
column3: is that what you're saying?

column1: Please proceed governor.
I want to make sure we get that for the record because it took the president 14 days before he called the attack in Benghazi an act of terror.
Get the transcript.
Can you say that a little louder
column2: Candy?

column1: This -- the administration -- the administration indicated this was a reaction to a video and was a spontaneous reaction.
It took them a long time to say this was a terrorist act by a terrorist group. And to suggest -- am I incorrect in that regard
column2: on Sunday
column3: the -- your secretary --

column1: Candy?
Excuse me. The ambassador of the United Nations went on the Sunday television shows and spoke about how --
Candy
column2: I'm --

column1: -- this was a spontaneous --
I'm happy to have a longer conversation --
-- about foreign policy.
OK. I'm happy to do that
column2: too.

column1: I just want to make sure that --
-- all of these wonderful folks are going to have a chance to get some of their questions answered.

column19: beef up our security and procedures
column20: not just in Libya
column21: but at every embassy and consulate in the region.'
column22: ""Number two
column23: investigate exactly what happened
column24: regardless of where the facts lead us
column25: to make sure folks are held accountable and it doesn't happen again.""
column26: ""And number three
column27: we are going to find out who did this and we're going to hunt them down
column28: because one of the things that I've said throughout my presidency is when folks mess with Americans
column29: we go after them.""
column30: 'Now Governor Romney had a very different response.'
column31: ""While we were still dealing with our diplomats being threatened
column32: Governor Romney put out a press release
column33: trying to make political points
column34: and that's not how a commander in chief operates.""
column35: ""You don't turn national security into a political issue.""
column36: ""Certainly not right when it's happening.""
column37: ""And people -- not everybody agrees with some of the decisions I've made.""
column38: 'But when it comes to our national security
column40: ""I said I'd end the war in Libya -- in -- in Iraq
column42: ""I said that we'd go after al-Qaeda and bin Laden
column43: we have.""
column44: ""I said we'd transition out of Afghanistan
column45: and start making sure that Afghans are responsible for their own security
column47: 'And when it comes to this issue
column48: when I say that we are going to find out exactly what happened
column49: everybody will be held accountable.'
column50: ""And I am ultimately responsible for what's taking place there because these are my folks
column51: and I'm the one who has to greet those coffins when they come home.""
column52: 'You know that I mean what I say.'
column53: ""Thank you Kerry for your question
column55: 'And -- and I -- I think the president just said correctly that the buck does stop at his desk and -- and he takes responsibility for -- for that -- for the failure in providing those security resources
column56: and -- and those terrible things may well happen from time to time.'
column57: ""I -- I'm -- I feel very deeply sympathetic for the families of those who lost loved ones.""
column58: ""And today there's a memorial service for one of those that was lost in this tragedy.""
column59: 'We -- we think of their families and care for them deeply.'
column60: 'There were other issues associated with this -- with this tragedy.'
column61: 'There were many days that passed before we knew whether this was a spontaneous demonstration
column62: or actually whether it was a terrorist attack.'
column63: 'And there was no demonstration involved.'
column64: 'It was a terrorist attack and it took a long time for that to be told to the American people.'
column66: or instead whether we just didn't know what happened
column67: you have to ask yourself why didn't we know five days later when the ambassador to the United Nations went on TV to say that this was a demonstration.""
column68: 'How could we have not known?'
column69: ""But I find more troubling than this
column70: that on -- on the day following the assassination of the United States ambassador
column71: the first time that's happened since 1979
column72: when -- when we have four Americans killed there
column73: when apparently we didn't know what happened
column75: the day after that happened
column76: flies to Las Vegas for a political fund-raiser
column77: then the next day to Colorado for another event
column78: other political event.""
column79: ""I think these -- these actions taken by a president and a leader have symbolic significance and perhaps even material significance in that you'd hope that during that time we could call in the people who were actually eyewitnesses.""
column80: ""We've read their accounts now about what happened.""
column81: 'It was very clear this was not a demonstration.'
column83: ""And this calls into question the president's whole policy in the Middle East.""
column84: ""Look what's happening in Syria
column85: in Egypt
column86: now in Libya.""
column87: 'Consider the distance between ourselves and -- and Israel
column88: the president said that -- that he was going to put daylight between us and Israel.'
column89: 'We have Iran four years closer to a nuclear bomb.'
column90: ""Syria -- Syria's not just a tragedy of 30
column91: 000 civilians being killed by a military
column92: but also a strategic -- strategically significant player for America.""
column93: ""The president's policies throughout the Middle East began with an apology tour and -- and -- and pursue a strategy of leading from behind
column94: and this strategy is unraveling before our very eyes.""
column95: 'Secretary Clinton has done an extraordinary job.'
column96: 'But she works for me.'
column97: ""I'm the president and I'm always responsible
column98: and that's why nobody's more interested in finding out exactly what happened than I do.""
column99: 'The day after the attack
column100: governor
column101: I stood in the Rose Garden and I told the American people in the world that we are going to find out exactly what happened.'
column102: ""That this was an act of terror and I also said that we're going to hunt down those who committed this crime.""

column2: '16Oct'
column3: 9)	" We're a nation that believes in the Second Amendment
column4: and I believe in the Second Amendment. We've got a long tradition of hunting and sportsmen and people who want to make sure they can protect themselves. But there have been too many instances during the course of my presidency
column5: where I've had to comfort families who have lost somebody. Most recently out in Aurora. You know
column6: just a couple of weeks ago
column7: actually
column8: probably about a month
column9: I saw a mother
column10: who I had met at the bedside of her son
column11: who had been shot in that theater.  And her son had been shot through the head. And we spent some time
column12: and we said a prayer and
column13: remarkably
column14: about two months later
column15: this young man and his mom showed up
column16: and he looked unbelievable
column17: good as new.  But there were a lot of families who didn't have that good fortune and whose sons or daughters or husbands didn't survive.  So my belief is that
column19: we have to enforce the laws we've already got
column20: make sure that we're keeping guns out of the hands of criminals
column21: those who are mentally ill. We've done a much better job in terms of background checks
column22: but we've got more to do when it comes to enforcement.  But I also share your belief that weapons that were designed for soldiers in war theaters don't belong on our streets. And so what I'm trying to do is to get a broader conversation about how do we reduce the violence generally. Part of it is seeing if we can get an assault weapons ban reintroduced. But part of it is also looking at other sources of the violence. Because frankly
column23: in my home town of Chicago
column24: there's an awful lot of violence and they're not using AK-47s. They're using cheap hand guns.  And so what can we do to intervene
column25: to make sure that young people have opportunity; that our schools are working; that if there's violence on the streets
column26: that working with faith groups and law enforcement
column27: we can catch it before it gets out of control.  And so what I want is a -- is a comprehensive strategy. Part of it is seeing if we can get automatic weapons that kill folks in amazing numbers out of the hands of criminals and the mentally ill. But part of it is also going deeper and seeing if we can get into these communities and making sure we catch violent impulses before they occur.

column1: Yeah
column2: I'm not in favor of new pieces of legislation on -- on guns and taking guns away or making certain guns illegal. We
column3: of course
column4: don't want to have automatic weapons
column5: and that's already illegal in this country to have automatic weapons. What I believe is we have to do
column6: as the president mentioned towards the end of his remarks there
column7: which is to make enormous efforts to enforce the gun laws that we have
column8: and to change the culture of violence that we have. And you ask how -- how are we going to do that? And there are a number of things. He mentioned good schools. I totally agree. We were able to drive our schools to be number one in the nation in my state. And I believe if we do a better job in education
column9: we'll -- we'll give people the -- the hope and opportunity they deserve and perhaps less violence from that. But let me mention another thing. And that is parents. We need moms and dads
column10: helping to raise kids. Wherever possible the -- the benefit of having two parents in the home
column11: and that's not always possible. A lot of great single moms
column12: single dads. But gosh to tell our kids that before they have babies
column13: they ought to think about getting married to someone
column14: that's a great idea.  Because if there's a two parent family
column15: the prospect of living in poverty goes down dramatically. The opportunities that the child will -- will be able to achieve increase dramatically. So we can make changes in the way our culture works to help bring people away from violence and give them opportunity
column16: and bring them in the American system. The -- the greatest failure we've had with regards to -- to gun violence in some respects is what -- what is known as Fast and Furious. Which was a program under this administration
column17: and how it worked exactly I think we don't know precisely
column18: where thousands of automatic
column19: and AK-47 type weapons were -- were given to people that ultimately gave them to -- to drug lords.  They used those weapons against -- against their own citizens and killed Americans with them. And this was a -- this was a program of the government. For what purpose it was put in place
column20: I can't imagine. But it's one of the great tragedies related to violence in our society which has occurred during this administration. Which I think the American people would like to understand fully
column21: it's been investigated to a degree
column22: but -- but the administration has carried out executive privilege to prevent all of the information from coming out.  I'd like to understand who it was that did this
column23: what the idea was behind it
column24: why it led to the violence
column25: thousands of guns going to Mexican drug lords. OBAMA: Candy?

column1: Well
column2: Candy
column3: actually
column4: in my state
column5: the pro-gun folks and the anti-gun folks came together and put together a piece of legislation. And it's referred to as an assault weapon ban
column6: but it had
column7: at the signing of the bill
column8: both the pro-gun and the anti-gun people came together
column9: because it provided opportunities for both that both wanted. There were hunting opportunities
column10: for instance
column11: that haven't previously been available and so forth
column12: so it was a mutually agreed- upon piece of legislation. That's what we need more of
column13: Candy. What we have right now in Washington is a place that's gridlocked.

column1: We have --
Candy?
-- we haven't had the leadership in Washington to work on a bipartisan basis. I was able to do that in my state and bring these two together.
The -- first of all
column2: I think Governor Romney was for an assault weapons ban before he was against it. And he said that the reason he changed his mind was
column3: in part
column4: because he was seeking the endorsement of the National Rifle Association. So that's on the record. But I think that one area we agree on is the important of parents and the importance of schools
column5: because I do believe that if our young people have opportunity
column6: then they are less likely to engage in these kinds of violent acts. We're not going to eliminate everybody who is mentally disturbed and we have got to make sure they don't get weapons.  But we can make a difference in terms ensuring that every young person in America
column7: regardless of where they come from
column8: what they look like
column9: have a chance to succeed.  And
column10: Candy
column11: we haven't had a chance to talk about education much
column12: but I think it is very important to understand that the reforms we've put in place
column13: working with 46 governors around the country
column14: are seeing schools that are some of the ones that are the toughest for kids starting to succeed. We're starting to see gains in math and science.  When it comes to community colleges
column15: we are setting up programs
column16: including with Nassau Community College
column17: to retrain workers
column18: including young people who may have dropped out of school but now are getting another chance
column19: training them for the jobs that exist right now.  And in fact
column20: employers are looking for skilled workers. And so we're matching them up. Giving them access to higher education. As I said
column21: we have made sure that millions of young people are able to get an education that they weren't able to get before.  Now...

column1: But -- but it'll -- it'll -- it'll be... (CROSSTALK)
... just one second.
Because -- because this is important. This is part of the choice in this election. When Governor Romney was asked whether teachers
column2: hiring more teachers was important to growing our economy
column3: Governor Romney said that doesn't grow our economy.  When -- when he was asked would class size...  (CROSSTALK)

column1: I understand.
But this will make a difference in terms of whether or not we can move this economy forward for these young people...
... and reduce our violence.

column2: '16Oct'
column3: 9)	" We're a nation that believes in the Second Amendment
column4: and I believe in the Second Amendment. We've got a long tradition of hunting and sportsmen and people who want to make sure they can protect themselves. But there have been too many instances during the course of my presidency
column5: where I've had to comfort families who have lost somebody. Most recently out in Aurora. You know
column6: just a couple of weeks ago
column7: actually
column8: probably about a month
column9: I saw a mother
column10: who I had met at the bedside of her son
column11: who had been shot in that theater.  And her son had been shot through the head. And we spent some time
column12: and we said a prayer and
column13: remarkably
column14: about two months later
column15: this young man and his mom showed up
column16: and he looked unbelievable
column17: good as new.  But there were a lot of families who didn't have that good fortune and whose sons or daughters or husbands didn't survive.  So my belief is that
column19: we have to enforce the laws we've already got
column20: make sure that we're keeping guns out of the hands of criminals
column21: those who are mentally ill. We've done a much better job in terms of background checks
column22: but we've got more to do when it comes to enforcement.  But I also share your belief that weapons that were designed for soldiers in war theaters don't belong on our streets. And so what I'm trying to do is to get a broader conversation about how do we reduce the violence generally. Part of it is seeing if we can get an assault weapons ban reintroduced. But part of it is also looking at other sources of the violence. Because frankly
column23: in my home town of Chicago
column24: there's an awful lot of violence and they're not using AK-47s. They're using cheap hand guns.  And so what can we do to intervene
column25: to make sure that young people have opportunity; that our schools are working; that if there's violence on the streets
column26: that working with faith groups and law enforcement
column27: we can catch it before it gets out of control.  And so what I want is a -- is a comprehensive strategy. Part of it is seeing if we can get automatic weapons that kill folks in amazing numbers out of the hands of criminals and the mentally ill. But part of it is also going deeper and seeing if we can get into these communities and making sure we catch violent impulses before they occur.

column1: Yeah
column2: I'm not in favor of new pieces of legislation on -- on guns and taking guns away or making certain guns illegal. We
column3: of course
column4: don't want to have automatic weapons
column5: and that's already illegal in this country to have automatic weapons. What I believe is we have to do
column6: as the president mentioned towards the end of his remarks there
column7: which is to make enormous efforts to enforce the gun laws that we have
column8: and to change the culture of violence that we have. And you ask how -- how are we going to do that? And there are a number of things. He mentioned good schools. I totally agree. We were able to drive our schools to be number one in the nation in my state. And I believe if we do a better job in education
column9: we'll -- we'll give people the -- the hope and opportunity they deserve and perhaps less violence from that. But let me mention another thing. And that is parents. We need moms and dads
column10: helping to raise kids. Wherever possible the -- the benefit of having two parents in the home
column11: and that's not always possible. A lot of great single moms
column12: single dads. But gosh to tell our kids that before they have babies
column13: they ought to think about getting married to someone
column14: that's a great idea.  Because if there's a two parent family
column15: the prospect of living in poverty goes down dramatically. The opportunities that the child will -- will be able to achieve increase dramatically. So we can make changes in the way our culture works to help bring people away from violence and give them opportunity
column16: and bring them in the American system. The -- the greatest failure we've had with regards to -- to gun violence in some respects is what -- what is known as Fast and Furious. Which was a program under this administration
column17: and how it worked exactly I think we don't know precisely
column18: where thousands of automatic
column19: and AK-47 type weapons were -- were given to people that ultimately gave them to -- to drug lords.  They used those weapons against -- against their own citizens and killed Americans with them. And this was a -- this was a program of the government. For what purpose it was put in place
column20: I can't imagine. But it's one of the great tragedies related to violence in our society which has occurred during this administration. Which I think the American people would like to understand fully
column21: it's been investigated to a degree
column22: but -- but the administration has carried out executive privilege to prevent all of the information from coming out.  I'd like to understand who it was that did this
column23: what the idea was behind it
column24: why it led to the violence
column25: thousands of guns going to Mexican drug lords. OBAMA: Candy?

column1: Well
column2: Candy
column3: actually
column4: in my state
column5: the pro-gun folks and the anti-gun folks came together and put together a piece of legislation. And it's referred to as an assault weapon ban
column6: but it had
column7: at the signing of the bill
column8: both the pro-gun and the anti-gun people came together
column9: because it provided opportunities for both that both wanted. There were hunting opportunities
column10: for instance
column11: that haven't previously been available and so forth
column12: so it was a mutually agreed- upon piece of legislation. That's what we need more of
column13: Candy. What we have right now in Washington is a place that's gridlocked.

column1: We have --
Candy?
-- we haven't had the leadership in Washington to work on a bipartisan basis. I was able to do that in my state and bring these two together.
The -- first of all
column2: I think Governor Romney was for an assault weapons ban before he was against it. And he said that the reason he changed his mind was
column3: in part
column4: because he was seeking the endorsement of the National Rifle Association. So that's on the record. But I think that one area we agree on is the important of parents and the importance of schools
column5: because I do believe that if our young people have opportunity
column6: then they are less likely to engage in these kinds of violent acts. We're not going to eliminate everybody who is mentally disturbed and we have got to make sure they don't get weapons.  But we can make a difference in terms ensuring that every young person in America
column7: regardless of where they come from
column8: what they look like
column9: have a chance to succeed.  And
column10: Candy
column11: we haven't had a chance to talk about education much
column12: but I think it is very important to understand that the reforms we've put in place
column13: working with 46 governors around the country
column14: are seeing schools that are some of the ones that are the toughest for kids starting to succeed. We're starting to see gains in math and science.  When it comes to community colleges
column15: we are setting up programs
column16: including with Nassau Community College
column17: to retrain workers
column18: including young people who may have dropped out of school but now are getting another chance
column19: training them for the jobs that exist right now.  And in fact
column20: employers are looking for skilled workers. And so we're matching them up. Giving them access to higher education. As I said
column21: we have made sure that millions of young people are able to get an education that they weren't able to get before.  Now...

column1: But -- but it'll -- it'll -- it'll be... (CROSSTALK)
... just one second.
Because -- because this is important. This is part of the choice in this election. When Governor Romney was asked whether teachers
column2: hiring more teachers was important to growing our economy
column3: Governor Romney said that doesn't grow our economy.  When -- when he was asked would class size...  (CROSSTALK)

column1: I understand.
But this will make a difference in terms of whether or not we can move this economy forward for these young people...
... and reduce our violence.

column3: 9)	" We're a nation that believes in the Second Amendment
column4: and I believe in the Second Amendment. We've got a long tradition of hunting and sportsmen and people who want to make sure they can protect themselves. But there have been too many instances during the course of my presidency
column5: where I've had to comfort families who have lost somebody. Most recently out in Aurora. You know
column6: just a couple of weeks ago
column7: actually
column8: probably about a month
column9: I saw a mother
column10: who I had met at the bedside of her son
column11: who had been shot in that theater.  And her son had been shot through the head. And we spent some time
column12: and we said a prayer and
column13: remarkably
column14: about two months later
column15: this young man and his mom showed up
column16: and he looked unbelievable
column17: good as new.  But there were a lot of families who didn't have that good fortune and whose sons or daughters or husbands didn't survive.  So my belief is that
column19: we have to enforce the laws we've already got
column20: make sure that we're keeping guns out of the hands of criminals
column21: those who are mentally ill. We've done a much better job in terms of background checks
column22: but we've got more to do when it comes to enforcement.  But I also share your belief that weapons that were designed for soldiers in war theaters don't belong on our streets. And so what I'm trying to do is to get a broader conversation about how do we reduce the violence generally. Part of it is seeing if we can get an assault weapons ban reintroduced. But part of it is also looking at other sources of the violence. Because frankly
column23: in my home town of Chicago
column24: there's an awful lot of violence and they're not using AK-47s. They're using cheap hand guns.  And so what can we do to intervene
column25: to make sure that young people have opportunity; that our schools are working; that if there's violence on the streets
column26: that working with faith groups and law enforcement
column27: we can catch it before it gets out of control.  And so what I want is a -- is a comprehensive strategy. Part of it is seeing if we can get automatic weapons that kill folks in amazing numbers out of the hands of criminals and the mentally ill. But part of it is also going deeper and seeing if we can get into these communities and making sure we catch violent impulses before they occur.

column1: Yeah
column2: I'm not in favor of new pieces of legislation on -- on guns and taking guns away or making certain guns illegal. We
column3: of course
column4: don't want to have automatic weapons
column5: and that's already illegal in this country to have automatic weapons. What I believe is we have to do
column6: as the president mentioned towards the end of his remarks there
column7: which is to make enormous efforts to enforce the gun laws that we have
column8: and to change the culture of violence that we have. And you ask how -- how are we going to do that? And there are a number of things. He mentioned good schools. I totally agree. We were able to drive our schools to be number one in the nation in my state. And I believe if we do a better job in education
column9: we'll -- we'll give people the -- the hope and opportunity they deserve and perhaps less violence from that. But let me mention another thing. And that is parents. We need moms and dads
column10: helping to raise kids. Wherever possible the -- the benefit of having two parents in the home
column11: and that's not always possible. A lot of great single moms
column12: single dads. But gosh to tell our kids that before they have babies
column13: they ought to think about getting married to someone
column14: that's a great idea.  Because if there's a two parent family
column15: the prospect of living in poverty goes down dramatically. The opportunities that the child will -- will be able to achieve increase dramatically. So we can make changes in the way our culture works to help bring people away from violence and give them opportunity
column16: and bring them in the American system. The -- the greatest failure we've had with regards to -- to gun violence in some respects is what -- what is known as Fast and Furious. Which was a program under this administration
column17: and how it worked exactly I think we don't know precisely
column18: where thousands of automatic
column19: and AK-47 type weapons were -- were given to people that ultimately gave them to -- to drug lords.  They used those weapons against -- against their own citizens and killed Americans with them. And this was a -- this was a program of the government. For what purpose it was put in place
column20: I can't imagine. But it's one of the great tragedies related to violence in our society which has occurred during this administration. Which I think the American people would like to understand fully
column21: it's been investigated to a degree
column22: but -- but the administration has carried out executive privilege to prevent all of the information from coming out.  I'd like to understand who it was that did this
column23: what the idea was behind it
column24: why it led to the violence
column25: thousands of guns going to Mexican drug lords. OBAMA: Candy?

column1: Well
column2: Candy
column3: actually
column4: in my state
column5: the pro-gun folks and the anti-gun folks came together and put together a piece of legislation. And it's referred to as an assault weapon ban
column6: but it had
column7: at the signing of the bill
column8: both the pro-gun and the anti-gun people came together
column9: because it provided opportunities for both that both wanted. There were hunting opportunities
column10: for instance
column11: that haven't previously been available and so forth
column12: so it was a mutually agreed- upon piece of legislation. That's what we need more of
column13: Candy. What we have right now in Washington is a place that's gridlocked.

column1: We have --
Candy?
-- we haven't had the leadership in Washington to work on a bipartisan basis. I was able to do that in my state and bring these two together.
The -- first of all
column2: I think Governor Romney was for an assault weapons ban before he was against it. And he said that the reason he changed his mind was
column3: in part
column4: because he was seeking the endorsement of the National Rifle Association. So that's on the record. But I think that one area we agree on is the important of parents and the importance of schools
column5: because I do believe that if our young people have opportunity
column6: then they are less likely to engage in these kinds of violent acts. We're not going to eliminate everybody who is mentally disturbed and we have got to make sure they don't get weapons.  But we can make a difference in terms ensuring that every young person in America
column7: regardless of where they come from
column8: what they look like
column9: have a chance to succeed.  And
column10: Candy
column11: we haven't had a chance to talk about education much
column12: but I think it is very important to understand that the reforms we've put in place
column13: working with 46 governors around the country
column14: are seeing schools that are some of the ones that are the toughest for kids starting to succeed. We're starting to see gains in math and science.  When it comes to community colleges
column15: we are setting up programs
column16: including with Nassau Community College
column17: to retrain workers
column18: including young people who may have dropped out of school but now are getting another chance
column19: training them for the jobs that exist right now.  And in fact
column20: employers are looking for skilled workers. And so we're matching them up. Giving them access to higher education. As I said
column21: we have made sure that millions of young people are able to get an education that they weren't able to get before.  Now...

column1: But -- but it'll -- it'll -- it'll be... (CROSSTALK)
... just one second.
Because -- because this is important. This is part of the choice in this election. When Governor Romney was asked whether teachers
column2: hiring more teachers was important to growing our economy
column3: Governor Romney said that doesn't grow our economy.  When -- when he was asked would class size...  (CROSSTALK)

column1: I understand.
But this will make a difference in terms of whether or not we can move this economy forward for these young people...
... and reduce our violence.

column3: 9)	" We're a nation that believes in the Second Amendment
column4: and I believe in the Second Amendment. We've got a long tradition of hunting and sportsmen and people who want to make sure they can protect themselves. But there have been too many instances during the course of my presidency
column5: where I've had to comfort families who have lost somebody. Most recently out in Aurora. You know
column6: just a couple of weeks ago
column7: actually
column8: probably about a month
column9: I saw a mother
column10: who I had met at the bedside of her son
column11: who had been shot in that theater.  And her son had been shot through the head. And we spent some time
column12: and we said a prayer and
column13: remarkably
column14: about two months later
column15: this young man and his mom showed up
column16: and he looked unbelievable
column17: good as new.  But there were a lot of families who didn't have that good fortune and whose sons or daughters or husbands didn't survive.  So my belief is that
column19: we have to enforce the laws we've already got
column20: make sure that we're keeping guns out of the hands of criminals
column21: those who are mentally ill. We've done a much better job in terms of background checks
column22: but we've got more to do when it comes to enforcement.  But I also share your belief that weapons that were designed for soldiers in war theaters don't belong on our streets. And so what I'm trying to do is to get a broader conversation about how do we reduce the violence generally. Part of it is seeing if we can get an assault weapons ban reintroduced. But part of it is also looking at other sources of the violence. Because frankly
column23: in my home town of Chicago
column24: there's an awful lot of violence and they're not using AK-47s. They're using cheap hand guns.  And so what can we do to intervene
column25: to make sure that young people have opportunity; that our schools are working; that if there's violence on the streets
column26: that working with faith groups and law enforcement
column27: we can catch it before it gets out of control.  And so what I want is a -- is a comprehensive strategy. Part of it is seeing if we can get automatic weapons that kill folks in amazing numbers out of the hands of criminals and the mentally ill. But part of it is also going deeper and seeing if we can get into these communities and making sure we catch violent impulses before they occur.

column1: Yeah
column2: I'm not in favor of new pieces of legislation on -- on guns and taking guns away or making certain guns illegal. We
column3: of course
column4: don't want to have automatic weapons
column5: and that's already illegal in this country to have automatic weapons. What I believe is we have to do
column6: as the president mentioned towards the end of his remarks there
column7: which is to make enormous efforts to enforce the gun laws that we have
column8: and to change the culture of violence that we have. And you ask how -- how are we going to do that? And there are a number of things. He mentioned good schools. I totally agree. We were able to drive our schools to be number one in the nation in my state. And I believe if we do a better job in education
column9: we'll -- we'll give people the -- the hope and opportunity they deserve and perhaps less violence from that. But let me mention another thing. And that is parents. We need moms and dads
column10: helping to raise kids. Wherever possible the -- the benefit of having two parents in the home
column11: and that's not always possible. A lot of great single moms
column12: single dads. But gosh to tell our kids that before they have babies
column13: they ought to think about getting married to someone
column14: that's a great idea.  Because if there's a two parent family
column15: the prospect of living in poverty goes down dramatically. The opportunities that the child will -- will be able to achieve increase dramatically. So we can make changes in the way our culture works to help bring people away from violence and give them opportunity
column16: and bring them in the American system. The -- the greatest failure we've had with regards to -- to gun violence in some respects is what -- what is known as Fast and Furious. Which was a program under this administration
column17: and how it worked exactly I think we don't know precisely
column18: where thousands of automatic
column19: and AK-47 type weapons were -- were given to people that ultimately gave them to -- to drug lords.  They used those weapons against -- against their own citizens and killed Americans with them. And this was a -- this was a program of the government. For what purpose it was put in place
column20: I can't imagine. But it's one of the great tragedies related to violence in our society which has occurred during this administration. Which I think the American people would like to understand fully
column21: it's been investigated to a degree
column22: but -- but the administration has carried out executive privilege to prevent all of the information from coming out.  I'd like to understand who it was that did this
column23: what the idea was behind it
column24: why it led to the violence
column25: thousands of guns going to Mexican drug lords. OBAMA: Candy?

column1: Well
column2: Candy
column3: actually
column4: in my state
column5: the pro-gun folks and the anti-gun folks came together and put together a piece of legislation. And it's referred to as an assault weapon ban
column6: but it had
column7: at the signing of the bill
column8: both the pro-gun and the anti-gun people came together
column9: because it provided opportunities for both that both wanted. There were hunting opportunities
column10: for instance
column11: that haven't previously been available and so forth
column12: so it was a mutually agreed- upon piece of legislation. That's what we need more of
column13: Candy. What we have right now in Washington is a place that's gridlocked.

column1: We have --
Candy?
-- we haven't had the leadership in Washington to work on a bipartisan basis. I was able to do that in my state and bring these two together.
The -- first of all
column2: I think Governor Romney was for an assault weapons ban before he was against it. And he said that the reason he changed his mind was
column3: in part
column4: because he was seeking the endorsement of the National Rifle Association. So that's on the record. But I think that one area we agree on is the important of parents and the importance of schools
column5: because I do believe that if our young people have opportunity
column6: then they are less likely to engage in these kinds of violent acts. We're not going to eliminate everybody who is mentally disturbed and we have got to make sure they don't get weapons.  But we can make a difference in terms ensuring that every young person in America
column7: regardless of where they come from
column8: what they look like
column9: have a chance to succeed.  And
column10: Candy
column11: we haven't had a chance to talk about education much
column12: but I think it is very important to understand that the reforms we've put in place
column13: working with 46 governors around the country
column14: are seeing schools that are some of the ones that are the toughest for kids starting to succeed. We're starting to see gains in math and science.  When it comes to community colleges
column15: we are setting up programs
column16: including with Nassau Community College
column17: to retrain workers
column18: including young people who may have dropped out of school but now are getting another chance
column19: training them for the jobs that exist right now.  And in fact
column20: employers are looking for skilled workers. And so we're matching them up. Giving them access to higher education. As I said
column21: we have made sure that millions of young people are able to get an education that they weren't able to get before.  Now...

column1: But -- but it'll -- it'll -- it'll be... (CROSSTALK)
... just one second.
Because -- because this is important. This is part of the choice in this election. When Governor Romney was asked whether teachers
column2: hiring more teachers was important to growing our economy
column3: Governor Romney said that doesn't grow our economy.  When -- when he was asked would class size...  (CROSSTALK)

column1: I understand.
But this will make a difference in terms of whether or not we can move this economy forward for these young people...
... and reduce our violence.
